scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Vessel B: Power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A is meeting vessel B on reciprocal courses so as to involve risk of collision Vessel A has vessel B right ahead (relative bearing 000°)

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 14(b), a head-on situation exists when vessel A sees vessel B ahead and by night could see the masthead lights in a line and/or both sidelights. According to Rule 14(a), when two power-driven vessels are meeting on reciprocal courses so as to involve risk of collision, each shall alter her course to starboard so that each shall pass on the port side of the other. Both vessels A and B are directed to keep out of the way of each other and shall take early and substantial action per Rule 16.
This is a head-on situation. Both vessels must alter course to starboard to pass port to port.
Vessel A should maintain course and speed while vessel B alters to starboard, as vessel A sighted vessel B first.

scenario: Vessel A: power-driven vessel Vessel B: power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A is overtaking vessel B Vessel B has vessel A on her own starboard side (relative bearing STBD 130°)

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 13(b), vessel A shall be deemed to be overtaking vessel B because she is coming up with vessel B from a direction more than 22.5° abaft her beam. Vessel A is in such a position that at night she would be able to see only the sternlight of vessel B but neither of her sidelights. According to Rule 13(a), any vessel overtaking any other shall keep out of the way of the vessel being overtaken. Therefore vessel A shall keep out of the way of vessel B.

Since vessel A is on the starboard side of vessel B, vessel B must give way under the crossing rules.

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 9(a), a vessel proceeding along the course of a narrow channel or fairway shall keep as near to the outer limit of the channel or fairway which lies on her starboard side as is safe and practicable. Both vessel A and vessel B shall keep to their starboard side of the channel.
Both vessels should keep to the starboard side of the narrow channel as they meet.

scenario: Vessel A: power-driven vessel Vessel B: power-driven vessel Area: Traffic separation scheme

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 10(b)(i), a vessel using a traffic separation scheme shall proceed in the appropriate traffic lane in the general direction of traffic flow for that lane. According to Rule 10(b)(ii), a vessel using a traffic separation scheme shall so far as practicable keep clear of a traffic separation line or separation zone.
Vessels must stay in the appropriate traffic lane and keep clear of the separation zone.
Vessels should proceed in any available lane that provides the shortest route to their destination.

scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Vessel B: Power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A and vessel B are crossing Vessel A has vessel B on her own starboard side (relative bearing STBD 054°) No change in bearing taken at interval of time, CPA=0

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 7, risk of collision shall be deemed to exist if the compass bearing of an approaching vessel does not appreciably change. Since the bearing remains constant at STBD 054° when taken at intervals, risk of collision shall be deemed to exist.
The bearing is not changing, therefore a risk of collision exists between the two vessels.
Since the CPA is zero, vessels should immediately take evasive action without determining if the bearing is changing.

scenario: Vessel A: power-driven vessel Vessel B: power-driven vessel Area: Traffic separation scheme Vessel A is joining a traffic lane at a termination of the lane Vessel B is joining a traffic lane from side

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 10(b)(iii), a vessel using a traffic separation scheme shall normally join a traffic lane at the termination of the lane. Vessel A is correctly joining at the termination. According to Rule 10(b)(iii), a vessel using a traffic separation scheme when joining from either side shall do so at as small an angle to the general direction of traffic flow as practicable. Vessel B shall join at a small angle to the traffic flow.
Vessel A should join at the termination while vessel B should join at a small angle to the traffic flow direction.
Both vessels should enter at right angles to the traffic flow to minimize time spent crossing lanes.

scenario: Vessel A: power-driven vessel Vessel B: power-driven vessel Area: Traffic separation scheme Vessel A is leaving a traffic lane at a termination of the lane Vessel B is leaving traffic lane from side

answers.answer: According to Rule 10(b)(iii), a vessel using a traffic separation scheme shall normally leave a traffic lane at the termination of the lane. In accordance with Rule 10(b)(iii), a vessel using a traffic separation scheme when leaving from either side shall do so at as small an angle to the general direction of traffic flow as practicable. Vessel B shall leave at a small angle.

scenario: Vessel A: power-driven vessel crossing traffic lanes Area: Traffic separation scheme

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 10(c), a vessel shall so far as practicable avoid crossing traffic lanes, but if obliged to do so shall cross on a heading as nearly as practicable at right angles to the general direction of traffic flow.
If vessel A must cross traffic lanes, she should cross at right angles to the traffic flow.
Vessel A should cross at the angle that provides the shortest distance across the lanes.

scenario: Vessel A: power-driven vessel Area: Traffic separation scheme

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 10(d)(i), a vessel shall not use an inshore traffic zone when she can safely use the appropriate traffic lane within the adjacent traffic separation scheme.
Vessel A should use the traffic lane instead of the inshore zone if it is safe to do so.
Vessel A may use the inshore zone if it provides a shorter route to her destination.

scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel of less than 20 m in length Vessel B: Sailing vessel Vessel C: Vessel engaged in fishing Area: Traffic separation scheme

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 10(d)(i), vessels of less than 20 m in length, sailing vessels and vessels engaged in fishing may use the inshore traffic zone. Therefore vessels A, B, and C may all use the inshore traffic zone.
All three vessels are permitted to use the inshore traffic zone under Rule 10.
Only vessel C engaged in fishing may use the inshore zone; vessels A and B must use the traffic lanes.

scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Area: Traffic separation scheme

answers.answer: According to Rule 10(d)(ii), a vessel may use an inshore traffic zone when en route to or from a port, offshore installation or structure, pilot station or any other place situated within the inshore traffic zone, or to avoid immediate danger.
Vessel A may use the inshore zone if going to a port or pilot station within the zone, or to avoid danger.
Vessel A may never use the inshore zone unless she is less than 20 meters in length.

scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Vessel B: Power-driven vessel Visibility: Restricted (vessels are not in sight of one another) Vessel A detects by radar alone the presence of vessel B Vessel A and vessel B are crossing so as to involve risk of collision Vessel A has vessel B on her own port side (relative bearing PORT 053°)
rule_refs: Rule 19 (Conduct of vessels in restricted visibility)

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 19(d), a vessel which detects by radar alone the presence of another vessel shall determine if a close-quarters situation is developing and/or risk of collision exists. If so, she shall take avoiding action in ample time, provided that when such action consists of an alteration of course, so far as possible the following shall be avoided: (i) an alteration of course to port for a vessel forward of the beam, other than for a vessel being overtaken. According to Rule 7(b), proper use shall be made of radar equipment if fitted and operational.
Vessel A should avoid altering course to port since vessel B is forward of the beam. Action should be taken in ample time.
Vessel A should alter course to port to keep clear of vessel B on her port side.

scenario: Visibility: Restricted (vessels not in sight of one another) Conduct of vessels in restricted visibility - safe speed
rule_refs: Rule 19 (Conduct of vessels in restricted visibility)

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 19(b), every vessel shall proceed at a safe speed adapted to the prevailing circumstances and conditions of restricted visibility. A power-driven vessel shall have her engines ready for immediate manoeuvre. According to Rule 6, every vessel shall at all times proceed at a safe speed so that she can take proper and effective action to avoid collision and be stopped within a distance appropriate to the prevailing circumstances and conditions.
Vessels must proceed at safe speed in restricted visibility and power-driven vessels must have engines ready for immediate manoeuvre.
Vessels should reduce to half speed in restricted visibility and sound fog signals continuously.

scenario: Visibility: Restricted (vessels not in sight of one another)
rule_refs: Rule 19 (Conduct of vessels in restricted visibility)

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 19(c), every vessel shall have due regard to the prevailing circumstances and conditions of restricted visibility when complying with the Rules of section I of part B.
Vessels must have due regard to restricted visibility conditions when applying Rules 4 through 10.
All steering and sailing rules are suspended in restricted visibility and only sound signal rules apply.

scenario: Visibility: Restricted (vessels are not in sight of one another) Vessel detects by sound signal the presence of another vessel
rule_refs: Rule 19 (Conduct of vessels in restricted visibility)

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 19(e), except where it has been determined that a risk of collision does not exist, every vessel which hears apparently forward of her beam the fog signal of another vessel, or which cannot avoid a close-quarters situation with another vessel forward of her beam, shall reduce her speed to the minimum at which she can be kept on her course. She shall if necessary take all her way off and in any event navigate with extreme caution until danger of collision is over. According to Rule 35, in or near an area of restricted visibility, whether by day or night, the signals prescribed in Rule 35 shall be used.
If a vessel hears a fog signal forward of the beam, she must reduce speed to minimum steerage way or stop if necessary and navigate with extreme caution.
The vessel should sound five short blasts and maintain course until the other vessel is sighted visually.

scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Vessel B: Power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A is overtaking vessel B on her starboard side Vessel A is astern of vessel B (relative bearing STBD/PORT 180°).

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 13(b), vessel A shall be deemed to be overtaking when coming up with vessel B from a direction more than 22.5 degrees abaft her beam. According to Rule 13(a), notwithstanding anything contained in the Rules of Part B, sections I and II, any vessel overtaking any other shall keep out of the way of the vessel being overtaken. Per Rule 13(d), any subsequent alteration of the bearing between the two vessels shall not make the overtaking vessel a crossing vessel or relieve her of the duty of keeping clear until she is finally past and clear. In accordance with Rule 16, vessel A shall take early and substantial action to keep well clear.
Vessel A is overtaking and must keep clear of vessel B. Even if the bearing changes, vessel A remains the give-way vessel until past and clear.
Once vessel A alters course and the bearing changes, the situation becomes a crossing situation and new rules apply.

scenario: Vessel A: sailing vessel Vessel B: power-driven vessel which can safely navigate only within a narrow channel or fairway Area: Narrow channel Vessel A and vessel B are crossing so as to involve risk of collision

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 9(b), a sailing vessel shall not impede the passage of a vessel which can safely navigate only within a narrow channel or fairway. Vessel A shall not impede the passage of vessel B.
Vessel A must not impede vessel B which is restricted to the narrow channel.
Vessel B must give way to vessel A under Rule 18 as power gives way to sail.

scenario: Vessel A: vessel engaged in fishing Vessel B: power-driven vessel Area: Narrow channel Vessel A and vessel B are crossing so as to involve risk of collision

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 9(c), a vessel engaged in fishing shall not impede the passage of any other vessel navigating within a narrow channel or fairway. Vessel A shall not impede the passage of vessel B.
Vessel A must not impede vessel B in the narrow channel.
Vessel B must keep clear of vessel A which is engaged in fishing and has limited maneuverability.

scenario: Vessel A: power-driven vessel Vessel B: power-driven vessel Area: Narrow channel Vessel A is intending to overtake vessel B on her starboard side

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 9(e)(i), in a narrow channel when overtaking can take place only if the vessel to be overtaken has to take action to permit safe passing, the vessel intending to overtake shall indicate her intention by sounding the appropriate signal prescribed in Rule 34(c)(i). Per Rule 34(c)(i), vessel A shall sound two prolonged blasts followed by one short blast. According to Rule 9(e)(i), vessel B shall, if in agreement, sound the signal prescribed in Rule 34(c)(ii): one prolonged, one short, one prolonged and one short blast. Rule 9(e)(ii) states this does not relieve the overtaking vessel of her obligation under Rule 13. Per Rule 13(a), vessel A shall keep out of the way of vessel B.
Vessel A must sound two prolonged and one short blast. If vessel B agrees, she sounds one prolonged, one short, one prolonged, one short. Vessel A must still keep clear under overtaking rules.
Vessel A should sound one short blast and overtake on the starboard side without waiting for vessel B's response.

scenario: Vessel A: power-driven vessel Vessel B: power-driven vessel Area: Narrow channel Vessel A is intending to overtake vessel B on her port side

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 9(e)(i), in a narrow channel when overtaking can take place only if the vessel to be overtaken has to take action to permit safe passing, the vessel intending to overtake shall indicate her intention by sounding the appropriate signal prescribed in Rule 34(c)(i). According to Rule 34(c)(i), vessel A shall sound two prolonged blasts followed by two short blasts to indicate intention to overtake on the port side. Per Rule 9(e)(i), vessel B shall, if in agreement, sound one prolonged, one short, one prolonged and one short blast. Rule 9(e)(ii) does not relieve vessel A of her obligation under Rule 13(a) to keep out of the way of vessel B.
Vessel A sounds two prolonged and two short blasts. Vessel B responds with agreement signal if in agreement. Vessel A must keep clear.
Vessel A should sound two short blasts and alter to port to overtake without agreement from vessel B.

scenario: Vessel A: power-driven vessel Vessel B: power-driven vessel Area: Narrow channel Vessel A and vessel B are nearing a bend or an area of a narrow channel or fairway where other vessels may be obscured by intervening obstruction

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 9(f), a vessel nearing a bend or an area of a narrow channel or fairway where other vessels may be obscured by an intervening obstruction shall navigate with particular alertness and caution and shall sound the appropriate signal prescribed in Rule 34(e). According to Rule 34(e), vessels A and B shall sound one prolonged blast.
Both vessels should navigate with caution and sound one prolonged blast when nearing the bend.
Vessels should reduce to slow speed and sound three short blasts to warn other traffic.

scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Vessel B: Power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A and vessel B are crossing Bearing of vessel B taken from vessel A at interval of time is increasing

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 7, risk of collision shall be deemed to exist if the compass bearing of an approaching vessel does not appreciably change. Since the bearing is increasing (appreciably changing), risk of collision shall not be deemed to exist based on this criterion.
The bearing is changing appreciably, therefore risk of collision does not exist.

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 13(b), vessel A shall be deemed to be overtaking vessel B. Per Rule 13(a), vessel A shall keep out of the way of vessel B. scenario: Vessel A: sailing vessel Vessel B: sailing vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A and vessel B are approaching one another, so as to involve risk of collision Vessel A has the wind on the port side Vessel B has the wind on the starboard side

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 12(a)(i), when two sailing vessels are approaching one another so as to involve risk of collision and when each has the wind on a different side, the vessel which has the wind on port side shall keep out of the way of the other. Vessel A has the wind on the port side, therefore vessel A shall keep out of the way of vessel B.

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 12(a)(ii), when two sailing vessels are approaching one another so as to involve risk of collision and when both have the wind on the same side, the vessel which is to windward shall keep out of the way of the vessel which is to leeward. Vessel A is to windward, therefore vessel A shall keep out of the way of vessel B. According to Rule 12(b), the windward side shall be deemed to be the side opposite to that on which the mainsail is carried.
Vessel A is to windward and must give way to vessel B which is to leeward.
The vessel with the most maneuverable sail configuration should give way to the other vessel.

scenario: Vessel A: sailing vessel Vessel B: sailing vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A and vessel B are approaching one another, so as to involve risk of collision Vessel A has the wind on the port side and sees vessel B to windward and cannot determine with certainty whether vessel B has the wind on the port or on the starboard side

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 12(a)(iii), when two sailing vessels are approaching one another so as to involve risk of collision and if a vessel with the wind on the port side sees a vessel to windward and cannot determine with certainty whether the other vessel has the wind on the port or on the starboard side, she shall keep out of the way of the other. According to Rule 12(b), the windward side shall be deemed to be the side opposite to that on which the mainsail is carried.

Vessel B may make a 360° turn to starboard when vessel A fails to give way. She should not alter to port for vessel A on her port side. Vessel A remains obligated to keep clear.

scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Vessel B: Power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A and vessel B are crossing so as to involve risk of collision Vessel B has vessel A on her own port side (relative bearing PORT 070°) Vessel A which is required to keep out of the way is not taking appropriate action in compliance with these Rules Vessel B which is the stand-on vessel is altering her course to starboard to approximately parallel course with vessel A and reducing her speed to avoid collision

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 15, vessel A which has vessel B on her starboard side shall keep out of the way and avoid crossing ahead of vessel B if circumstances permit. According to Rule 17(a)(ii), vessel B may take action to avoid collision by her manoeuvre alone as soon as it becomes apparent that vessel A is not taking appropriate action. Per Rule 17(b), when vessel B finds herself so close that collision cannot be avoided by the action of vessel A alone, she shall take such action as will best aid to avoid collision. In accordance with Rule 17(c), a power-driven vessel which takes action in a crossing situation shall, if the circumstances of the case admit, not alter course to port for a vessel on her own port side. Rule 17(d) does not relieve vessel A of her obligation to keep out of the way.
Vessel B may alter to starboard and reduce speed when vessel A fails to give way. She should not alter to port. Vessel A remains the give-way vessel.
Vessel B should only alter course or only reduce speed, not both simultaneously as this creates confusion.

scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Vessel B: Power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A and vessel B are crossing so as to involve risk of collision Vessel B has vessel A on her own port side (relative bearing PORT 070°) Vessel A which is required to keep out of the way is not taking appropriate action in compliance with these Rules Vessel B which is the stand-on vessel is reducing speed to avoid collision

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 15, vessel A which has vessel B on her starboard side shall keep out of the way and avoid crossing ahead of vessel B if circumstances permit. According to Rule 17(a)(ii), vessel B may take action to avoid collision by her manoeuvre alone as soon as it becomes apparent that vessel A is not taking appropriate action. Per Rule 17(b), when vessel B finds herself so close that collision cannot be avoided by the action of vessel A alone, she shall take such action as will best aid to avoid collision. In accordance with Rule 17(c), a power-driven vessel which takes action in a crossing situation shall, if the circumstances of the case admit, not alter course to port for a vessel on her own port side. Rule 17(d) does not relieve vessel A of her obligation to keep out of the way.
Vessel B may reduce speed when vessel A is not giving way. She should not alter to port. Vessel A remains obligated to keep clear.
Vessel B should increase speed to pass ahead of vessel A rather than reducing speed.

scenario: Vessel A: power-driven vessel Vessel B: power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A is meeting vessel B on nearly reciprocal courses so as to involve risk of collision Vessel A has vessel B nearly ahead on PORT bow

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 14(b), a head-on situation shall be deemed to exist when vessel A sees vessel B nearly ahead and by night could see the masthead lights nearly in a line and/or both sidelights and by day observes the corresponding aspect of the other vessel. According to Rule 14(c), when vessel A is in any doubt as to whether such a situation exists she shall assume that it does exist and act accordingly.
This is a head-on situation on nearly reciprocal courses. If in doubt, both vessels should assume it is head-on and alter to starboard.
Since vessel B is on the port bow, vessel B must give way to vessel A under crossing rules.

scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Vessel B: Power-driven vessel Area: Traffic separation scheme Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A is overtaking vessel B

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 10(a), Rule 10 applies to traffic separation schemes adopted by the Organization and does not relieve any vessel of her obligation under any other rule. According to Rule 10(b)(i), a vessel using a traffic separation scheme shall proceed in the appropriate traffic lane in the general direction of traffic flow for that lane. In accordance with Rule 13(a), notwithstanding anything contained in the Rules of part B, sections I and II, any vessel overtaking any other shall keep out of the way of the vessel being overtaken. Vessel A shall keep out of the way of vessel B. Per Rule 16, vessel A shall take early and substantial action to keep well clear.
Even in a traffic separation scheme, vessel A as the overtaking vessel must keep clear of vessel B.
In a traffic separation scheme, vessels must maintain position in their lane and overtaking is not permitted.

scenario: Vessel A: power-driven vessel using traffic separation scheme Vessel B: power-driven vessel of 20 m or more in length crossing traffic separation scheme Area: Traffic separation scheme Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A and vessel B are crossing so as to involve risk of collision Vessel A has vessel B on her own starboard side

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 10(c), vessel B shall so far as practicable avoid crossing traffic lanes, but if obliged to do so shall cross on a heading as nearly as practicable at right angles to the general direction of traffic flow. According to Rule 15, when two power-driven vessels are crossing so as to involve risk of collision, the vessel which has the other on her own starboard side shall keep out of the way. Vessel A has vessel B on her starboard side, therefore vessel A shall keep out of the way. Vessel A shall avoid crossing ahead of vessel B if circumstances permit. Per Rule 16, vessel A shall take early and substantial action to keep well clear.
Vessel A must give way because vessel B is on her starboard side. Vessel B should cross at right angles to the traffic flow.
Vessel B crossing the scheme must give way to all vessels in the traffic lanes regardless of position.

scenario: Vessel A: power-driven vessel using traffic separation scheme Vessel B: power-driven vessel of 20 m or more in length crossing traffic separation scheme Area: Traffic separation scheme Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A and vessel B are crossing so as to involve risk of collision Vessel A has vessel B on her own port side

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 10(c), vessel B shall so far as practicable avoid crossing traffic lanes, but if obliged to do so shall cross on a heading as nearly as practicable at right angles to the general direction of traffic flow. According to Rule 15, when two power-driven vessels are crossing so as to involve risk of collision, the vessel which has the other on her own starboard side shall keep out of the way. Vessel A has vessel B on her port side, meaning vessel B has vessel A on her starboard side. Therefore vessel B shall keep out of the way of vessel A. Vessel B shall avoid crossing ahead of vessel A if circumstances permit. Per Rule 16, vessel B shall take early and substantial action to keep well clear.
Vessel B must give way because vessel A is on her starboard side. Vessel B should cross the traffic lane at right angles.
Vessel A has priority in the traffic lane and vessel B on her port side must always wait until vessel A passes.

scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel underway Vessel B: Vessel not under command Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A and vessel B are crossing so as to involve risk of collision Vessel A has vessel B on her own port side (relative bearing PORT 070°) Vessel B is exhibiting signals in compliance with Rule 27 (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre)

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 18(a)(i), except where Rule 9, Rule 10 and Rule 13 otherwise require, a power-driven vessel underway shall keep out of the way of a vessel not under command. Vessel A shall keep out of the way of vessel B. According to Rule 16, vessel A which is directed to keep out of the way shall take early and substantial action to keep well clear.
Power-driven vessels must give way to vessels not under command. Vessel A must keep clear of vessel B.
Vessel B on the port side must give way to vessel A under normal crossing rules.

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 15, when two power-driven vessels are crossing so as to involve risk of collision, the vessel which has the other on her own starboard side shall keep out of the way. Vessel A has vessel B on her starboard side, therefore vessel A shall keep out of the way. Vessel A shall avoid crossing ahead of vessel B if circumstances permit. According to Rule 16, vessel A shall take early and substantial action to keep well clear.
Vessel A is the give-way vessel and making a 360° turn to starboard is one way to avoid crossing ahead of vessel B.
A 360° turn is excessive and vessel A should only make a small course alteration to starboard of 10-20 degrees.

scenario: Vessel A: power-driven vessel Vessel B: power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A has vessel B on her own starboard side (relative bearing STBD 070°) Vessel A and vessel B are crossing so as to involve risk of collision Vessel A is making 360° turn to port to avoid collision with vessel B

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 15, when two power-driven vessels are crossing so as to involve risk of collision, the vessel which has the other on her own starboard side shall keep out of the way. Vessel A has vessel B on her starboard side, therefore vessel A shall keep out of the way. Vessel A shall avoid crossing ahead of vessel B if circumstances permit. According to Rule 16, vessel A shall take early and substantial action to keep well clear.
Vessel A must give way and a 360° turn to port is acceptable action to keep clear, though turning to starboard might be more conventional.
Vessel A must never turn to port when vessel B is on her starboard side; she must only turn to starboard.

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 15, when two power-driven vessels are crossing so as to involve risk of collision, the vessel which has the other on her own starboard side shall keep out of the way. Vessel A has vessel B on her starboard side, therefore vessel A shall keep out of the way. Vessel A shall avoid crossing ahead of vessel B if circumstances permit. According to Rule 16, vessel A shall take early and substantial action to keep well clear.
Vessel A is giving way by altering to parallel course with vessel B and reducing speed to pass astern, which avoids crossing ahead.

scenario: Vessel A: power-driven vessel Vessel B: power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A has vessel B on her own starboard side (relative bearing STBD 070°) Vessel A and vessel B are crossing so as to involve risk of collision Vessel A is reducing speed to avoid collision with vessel B

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 15, when two power-driven vessels are crossing so as to involve risk of collision, the vessel which has the other on her own starboard side shall keep out of the way. Vessel A has vessel B on her starboard side, therefore vessel A shall keep out of the way. Vessel A shall avoid crossing ahead of vessel B if circumstances permit. According to Rule 16, vessel A shall take early and substantial action to keep well clear.

scenario: Vessel A: power-driven vessel, proceeding in appropriate traffic lane Vessel B: power-driven vessel, proceeding in appropriate traffic lane Vessel C: power-driven vessel, crossing traffic lanes Area: Traffic separation scheme Vessel A and vessel C are crossing so as to involve risk of collision Vessel B is overtaking vessel A

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 10(e)(i), a vessel, other than a crossing vessel, or a vessel joining or leaving a lane shall not normally enter a separation zone or cross a separation line except in cases of emergency to avoid immediate danger.
Vessels should not enter the separation zone except in emergency situations to avoid immediate danger.
Vessels may cross the separation zone whenever it provides a shorter route or better positioning in the traffic lane.

scenario: Vessel A: Vessel engaged in fishing Area: Traffic separation scheme

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 10(e)(ii), a vessel, other than a crossing vessel, or a vessel joining or leaving a lane shall not normally enter a separation zone or cross a separation line except to engage in fishing within a separation zone.
A vessel engaged in fishing may enter the separation zone to engage in fishing activities.
Fishing vessels must never enter separation zones as they would obstruct traffic flow.

scenario: Vessel navigating in areas near the terminations of traffic separation scheme Area: Traffic separation scheme

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 10(f), a vessel navigating in areas near the terminations of traffic separation schemes shall do so with particular caution.
Vessels should navigate with particular caution near the terminations of traffic separation schemes.
Vessels should increase speed near terminations to clear the area quickly and reduce congestion.

scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Vessel B: Vessel engaged in fishing Area: Traffic separation scheme

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 10(i), a vessel engaged in fishing shall not impede the passage of any vessel following a traffic lane.
Vessel B engaged in fishing must not impede vessel A which is following the traffic lane.
Vessel A must give way to vessel B which is engaged in fishing and has priority under Rule 18.

scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Vessel B: Power-driven vessel Vessel C: Vessel of less than 20 meters in length Vessel D: Sailing vessel Area: Traffic separation scheme

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 10(j), a vessel of less than 20 m in length shall not impede the safe passage of a power-driven vessel following a traffic lane. According to Rule 10(j), a sailing vessel shall not impede the safe passage of a power-driven vessel following a traffic lane. Therefore vessels C and D shall not impede vessels A and B.
Vessels less than 20 meters and sailing vessels must not impede power-driven vessels following traffic lanes.
Sailing vessels have priority over power-driven vessels in all situations including traffic separation schemes.

scenario: Type of vessel: WIG craft Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 23(c), a WIG craft only when taking off, landing and in flight near the surface shall, in addition to the lights prescribed in Rule 23(a), exhibit a high intensity all-round flashing red light.
WIG craft when taking off, landing or in flight near the surface must show an additional high intensity all-round flashing red light.
WIG craft should exhibit the same lights as seaplanes with no additional special signals required.

scenario: Type of vessel: Power-driven vessel towing, length of the tow exceeds 200 m Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 24(a), a power-driven vessel when towing shall exhibit: (i) instead of the light prescribed in Rule 23(a)(i) or (a)(ii), three masthead lights in a vertical line; (ii) sidelights; (iii) a sternlight; (iv) a towing light in a vertical line above the sternlight. According to Rule 24(e), a vessel or object being towed, other than those mentioned in Rule 24(g), shall exhibit: (i) sidelights; (ii) a sternlight.
When the tow exceeds 200 meters, the towing vessel shows three masthead lights in vertical line, sidelights, sternlight and towing light. The vessel being towed shows sidelights and sternlight.
A towing vessel shows two masthead lights regardless of tow length, with the towed vessel showing only a sternlight.

scenario: Type of vessel: Power-driven vessel towing, length of the tow exceeds 200 m Time of the day: Daytime

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 24(a)(v), a power-driven vessel when towing shall exhibit a diamond shape where it can best be seen. According to Rule 24(e)(iii), a vessel or object being towed, other than those mentioned in paragraph (g) of Rule 24, shall exhibit a diamond shape where it can best be seen.
Both the towing vessel and the vessel being towed must display a diamond shape when the tow exceeds 200 meters.
Only the vessel being towed needs to show a diamond shape; the towing vessel shows no daylight signals.

scenario: Type of vessel: Power-driven vessel pushing a vessel ahead while they are rigidly connected in a composite unit of more than 50 m in length Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 24(b), when a pushing vessel and a vessel being pushed ahead are rigidly connected in a composite unit they shall be regarded as a power-driven vessel and exhibit the lights prescribed in Rule 23. According to Rule 23(a), a power-driven vessel underway of more than 50 m in length, shall exhibit: (i) a masthead light forward; (ii) a second masthead light abaft of and higher than the forward one; (iii) sidelights; (iv) a sternlight.
When rigidly connected as a composite unit over 50 meters, they show lights as one power-driven vessel: two masthead lights, sidelights and sternlight.
The pushing vessel shows two masthead lights in vertical line while the vessel being pushed shows only sidelights at the forward end.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel not under command when making way through the water Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
rule_refs: Rule 27 (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre)

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 27(a), a vessel not under command shall exhibit: (i) two all-round red lights in a vertical line where they can best be seen; (iii) sidelights and a sternlight.
A vessel not under command making way shows two all-round red lights in vertical line, plus sidelights and sternlight.
A vessel not under command shows three red lights in vertical line without any sidelights or sternlight.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel not under command when not making way through the water Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
rule_refs: Rule 27 (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre)

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 27(a), a vessel not under command shall exhibit: (i) two all-round red lights in a vertical line where they can best be seen.
When not making way, a vessel not under command shows only two all-round red lights in vertical line.
The vessel must show all lights including sidelights and sternlight even when not making way.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel not under command Time of the day: Daytime
rule_refs: Rule 27 (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre)

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 27(a), a vessel not under command shall exhibit: (ii) two balls or similar shapes in a vertical line where they can best be seen.
A vessel not under command displays two balls in vertical line during daytime.
During daytime, a vessel not under command shows three balls in vertical line.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre when making way through the water Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
rule_refs: Rule 27 (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre)

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 27(b), a vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre, except a vessel engaged in mine clearance operations, shall exhibit: (i) three all-round lights in a vertical line where they can best be seen. The highest and lowest of these lights shall be red and the middle light shall be white; (iii) a masthead light or lights, sidelights and a sternlight.
A vessel restricted in ability to manoeuvre making way shows three all-round lights (red-white-red) in vertical line, plus masthead light(s), sidelights and sternlight.
The vessel shows only two red lights in vertical line with sidelights and sternlight, no white light is required.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre when not making way through the water Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
rule_refs: Rule 27 (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre)

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 27(b), a vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre, except a vessel engaged in mine clearance operations, shall exhibit: (i) three all-round lights in a vertical line where they can best be seen. The highest and lowest of these lights shall be red and the middle light shall be white.
When not making way, shows three all-round lights in vertical line: red, white, red.
The vessel shows the same lights whether making way or not, including sidelights and sternlight.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre Time of the day: Daytime
rule_refs: Rule 27 (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre)

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 27(b), a vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre, except a vessel engaged in mine clearance operations, shall exhibit: (ii) three shapes in a vertical line where they can best be seen. The highest and lowest of these shapes shall be balls and the middle one a diamond.
During daytime, displays three shapes in vertical line: ball, diamond, ball.
Shows three balls in vertical line during daytime, with no diamond shape required.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre of more than 100 m in length when at anchor Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
rule_refs: Rule 27 (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre)

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 27(b), a vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre shall exhibit: (i) three all-round lights in a vertical line where they can best be seen. The highest and lowest of these lights shall be red and the middle light shall be white; (iv) the light or lights prescribed in Rule 30. According to Rule 30(a), a vessel at anchor shall exhibit: (i) in the fore part, an all-round white light; (ii) at or near the stern and at a lower level, an all-round white light. Per Rule 30(c), a vessel of 100 m and more in length at anchor shall also use the available working or equivalent lights to illuminate her decks.
Shows three lights red-white-red in vertical line, plus anchor lights fore and aft, and deck illumination for vessels over 100 meters.
At anchor, the vessel shows only the anchor lights and does not need to display the red-white-red lights.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre when at anchor Time of the day: Daytime
rule_refs: Rule 27 (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre)

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 27(b), a vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre shall exhibit: (ii) three shapes in a vertical line where they can best be seen. The highest and lowest of these shapes shall be balls and the middle one a diamond; (iv) shape prescribed in Rule 30. According to Rule 30(a)(i), a vessel at anchor shall exhibit where it can best be seen, in the fore part, one ball.
At anchor during daytime, shows three shapes ball-diamond-ball in vertical line, plus one ball in the fore part.
Only the anchor ball is required during daytime; the ball-diamond-ball shapes are not displayed when at anchor.

scenario: Type of vessel: Power-driven vessel engaged in a towing operation such as severely restricts the towing vessel and her tow in their ability to deviate from their course, length of the tow exceeds 200 m Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
rule_refs: Rule 27 (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre)

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 27(c), a power-driven vessel engaged in a towing operation such as severely restricts the towing vessel and her tow in their ability to deviate from their course shall, in addition to the lights prescribed in Rule 24(a), exhibit the lights prescribed in subparagraphs (b)(i) of Rule 27. According to Rule 24(a), a power-driven vessel when towing shall exhibit: (i) three masthead lights in a vertical line; (ii) sidelights; (iii) a sternlight; (iv) a towing light in a vertical line above the sternlight. Per Rule 27(b), shall exhibit: (i) three all-round lights in a vertical line where they can best be seen. The highest and lowest of these lights shall be red and the middle light shall be white.
Shows towing lights (three masthead lights, sidelights, sternlight, towing light) plus three all-round lights red-white-red in vertical line to indicate restricted ability to manoeuvre.
Shows only the standard towing lights without any additional lights to indicate restricted manoeuvrability.

scenario: Type of vessel: Power-driven vessel engaged in a towing operation such as severely restricts the towing vessel and her tow in their ability to deviate from their course, length of the tow exceeds 200 m Time of the day: Daytime
rule_refs: Rule 27 (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre)

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 27(c), a power-driven vessel engaged in a towing operation such as severely restricts the towing vessel and her tow in their ability to deviate from their course shall, in addition to the shapes prescribed in Rule 24(a), exhibit the shapes prescribed in subparagraphs (b)(ii) of Rule 27. According to Rule 24(a)(v), a power-driven vessel when towing shall exhibit a diamond shape where it can best be seen. Per Rule 27(b), shall exhibit: (ii) three shapes in a vertical line where they can best be seen. The highest and lowest of these shapes shall be balls and the middle one a diamond.
Shows diamond shape for towing plus three shapes in vertical line: ball, diamond, ball to indicate restricted manoeuvrability.
Only displays a single diamond shape; no additional shapes are required for restricted manoeuvrability during towing.

scenario: Type of vessel: Power-driven vessel towing alongside Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 24(c), a power-driven vessel when towing alongside, except in the case of a composite unit, shall exhibit: (i) instead of the light prescribed in Rule 23(a)(i) or (a)(ii), two masthead lights in a vertical line; (ii) sidelights; (iii) a sternlight. According to Rule 24(f)(ii), a vessel being towed alongside shall exhibit a sternlight and at the forward end, sidelights.
Towing vessel shows two masthead lights in vertical line, sidelights and sternlight. Vessel being towed shows sidelights forward and sternlight.
Towing alongside requires three masthead lights in vertical line to distinguish it from towing astern.

scenario: Type of vessel: Power-driven vessel pushing ahead Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 24(c), a power-driven vessel when pushing ahead, except in the case of a composite unit, shall exhibit: (i) instead of the light prescribed in Rule 23(a)(i) or (a)(ii), two masthead lights in a vertical line; (ii) sidelights; (iii) a sternlight. According to Rule 24(f)(i), a vessel being pushed ahead, not being part of a composite unit, shall exhibit at the forward end, sidelights.
Pushing vessel shows two masthead lights in vertical line, sidelights and sternlight. Vessel being pushed shows sidelights at forward end.
The vessel being pushed ahead shows no lights at all; only the pushing vessel displays lights.

scenario: Type of vessel: Power-driven vessel towing partly submerged vessel of less than 25 m in breadth and its length does not exceed 100 m, length of the tow does not exceed 200 m Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 24(a), a power-driven vessel when towing shall exhibit: (i) instead of the light prescribed in Rule 23(a)(i) or (a)(ii), two masthead lights in a vertical line; (ii) sidelights; (iii) a sternlight; (iv) a towing light in a vertical line above the sternlight. According to Rule 24(g)(i), an inconspicuous, partly submerged vessel being towed, shall exhibit one all-round white light at or near the forward end and one at or near the after end.
Towing vessel shows two masthead lights, sidelights, sternlight and towing light. The partly submerged vessel shows one white light forward and one aft.
A partly submerged vessel shows sidelights and sternlight like any other towed vessel.

scenario: Type of vessel: Power-driven vessel towing partly submerged dracone of less than 25 m in breadth and its length does not exceed 100 m, length of the tow does not exceed 200 m Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 24(a), a power-driven vessel when towing shall exhibit: (i) instead of the light prescribed in Rule 23(a)(i) or (a)(ii), two masthead lights in a vertical line; (ii) sidelights; (iii) a sternlight; (iv) a towing light in a vertical line above the sternlight. According to Rule 24(g)(i), an inconspicuous, partly submerged dracone being towed, shall exhibit one all-round white light at or near the after end. Per Rule 24(g)(i), dracones need not exhibit an all-round white light near the forward end but may do so.
Towing vessel shows two masthead lights, sidelights, sternlight and towing light. Dracone shows one white light aft and may optionally show one forward.
Dracones must show two white lights, one forward and one aft, without exception.

scenario: Type of vessel: Power-driven vessel towing an incospicuous, partly submerged vessel with breadth of more than 25 m and length exceeding 100 m, length of the tow exceeds 200 m Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 24(a), a power-driven vessel when towing shall exhibit: (i) instead of the light prescribed in Rule 23(a)(i) or (a)(ii), three masthead lights in a vertical line; (ii) sidelights; (iii) a sternlight; (iv) a towing light in a vertical line above the sternlight. According to Rule 24(g), an inconspicuous, partly submerged vessel being towed, shall exhibit: (i) one all-round white light at or near the forward end and one at or near the after end; (ii) two additional all-round white lights at or near the extremities of its breadth; (iii) additional all-round white lights between the lights prescribed in sub-paragraphs (i) and (ii) so that the distance between the lights shall not exceed 100 m.

Towing vessel shows three masthead lights, sidelights, sternlight and towing light. Partly submerged vessel shows white lights at forward and after ends, at breadth extremities, and additional lights so spacing does not exceed 100 meters.
Large partly submerged vessels only need to show one white light at each end, regardless of breadth or length.

scenario: Type of vessel: Power-driven vessel towing an inconspicuous, partly submerged vessel, length of the tow exceeds 200 m Time of the day: Daytime

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 24(a)(v), a power-driven vessel when towing shall exhibit a diamond shape where it can best be seen. According to Rule 24(g)(iv), an inconspicuous, partly submerged vessel being towed, shall exhibit a diamond shape at or near the aftermost extremity of vessel being towed and an additional diamond shape where it can best be seen and located as far forward as is practicable.
Towing vessel shows one diamond. Partly submerged vessel shows one diamond aft and one diamond as far forward as practicable.
Only the towing vessel displays a diamond shape; the partly submerged vessel shows no shapes during daytime.

scenario: Type of vessel: Power-driven vessel towing an inconspicuous, partly submerged vessel, length of the tow does not exceed 200 m Time of the day: Daytime

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 24(g)(iv), an inconspicuous, partly submerged vessel being towed, shall exhibit a diamond shape at or near the aftermost extremity of vessel being towed.
The partly submerged vessel shows one diamond shape at the aftermost extremity.
When tow is under 200 meters, no diamond shapes are required on the partly submerged vessel.

scenario: Type of vessel: Power-driven vessel towing alongside a group of vessels Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 24(c), a power-driven vessel when towing alongside, except in the case of a composite unit, shall exhibit: (i) instead of the light prescribed in Rule 23(a)(i) or (a)(ii), two masthead lights in a vertical line; (ii) sidelights; (iii) a sternlight. According to Rule 24(f)(ii), vessels being towed alongside in a group shall be lighted as one vessel and shall exhibit a sternlight and at the forward end, sidelights.
Towing vessel shows two masthead lights, sidelights and sternlight. The group being towed is lit as one vessel with sidelights forward and sternlight.
Each vessel in the group being towed must show individual sidelights and sternlights.

scenario: Type of vessel: Power-driven vessel pushing ahead a group of vessels Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 24(c), a power-driven vessel when pushing ahead, except in the case of a composite unit, shall exhibit: (i) instead of the light prescribed in Rule 23(a)(i) or (a)(ii), two masthead lights in a vertical line; (ii) sidelights; (iii) a sternlight. According to Rule 24(f)(i), vessels being pushed ahead in a group shall be lighted as one vessel and shall exhibit at the forward end, sidelights.
Pushing vessel shows two masthead lights, sidelights and sternlight. The group being pushed is lit as one vessel with sidelights at the forward end.
Each vessel in the group must show its own individual sidelights and the aftermost vessel shows a sternlight.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel engaged in underwater operations, when restricted in her ability to manoeuvre, making way through the water and an obstruction exists on her port side Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
rule_refs: Rule 27 (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre)

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 27(d), a vessel engaged in underwater operations, when restricted in her ability to manoeuvre, shall exhibit the lights prescribed in Rule 27(b)(i) and (iii) and shall in addition, when an obstruction exists, exhibit: (i) two all-round red lights in a vertical line to indicate the side on which the obstruction exists; (ii) two all-round green lights in a vertical line to indicate the side on which another vessel may pass. According to Rule 27(b), a vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre shall exhibit: (i) three all-round lights in a vertical line where they can best be seen. The highest and lowest of these lights shall be red and the middle light shall be white; (iii) a masthead light or lights, sidelights and a sternlight.

Shows red-white-red lights in vertical line, masthead light(s), sidelights and sternlight. Additionally shows two red lights in vertical line on port side (obstruction side) and two green lights in vertical line on starboard side (clear side).
Shows only the standard red-white-red lights without any additional lights to indicate the obstruction location.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel engaged in underwater operations, when restricted in her ability to manoeuvre, not making way through the water and an obstruction exists on her port side Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
rule_refs: Rule 27 (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre)

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 27(d), a vessel engaged in underwater operations, when restricted in her ability to manoeuvre, shall exhibit the lights prescribed in Rule 27(b)(i) and shall in addition, when an obstruction exists, exhibit: (i) two all-round red lights in a vertical line to indicate the side on which the obstruction exists; (ii) two all-round green lights in a vertical line to indicate the side on which another vessel may pass. According to Rule 27(b)(i), a vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre shall exhibit three all-round lights in a vertical line where they can best be seen. The highest and lowest of these lights shall be red and the middle light shall be white.
Not making way, shows red-white-red lights in vertical line, plus two red lights on port side (obstruction) and two green lights on starboard side (clear).
When not making way, the vessel shows only anchor lights and does not display the red-white-red or obstruction lights.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel engaged in underwater operations, when restricted in her ability to manoeuvre, at anchor and an obstruction exists on her port side Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
rule_refs: Rule 27 (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre)

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 27(d), a vessel engaged in underwater operations, when restricted in her ability to manoeuvre, shall exhibit the lights prescribed in Rule 27(b)(i) and shall in addition, when an obstruction exists, exhibit: (iii) when at anchor, the lights prescribed in subparagraphs (i) and (ii) instead of the lights prescribed in Rule 30; (i) two all-round red lights in a vertical line to indicate the side on which the obstruction exists; (ii) two all-round green lights in a vertical line to indicate the side on which another vessel may pass. According to Rule 27(b)(i), shall exhibit three all-round lights in a vertical line where they can best be seen. The highest and lowest of these lights shall be red and the middle light shall be white.
At anchor, shows red-white-red lights in vertical line, plus two red lights on port side (obstruction) and two green lights on starboard side (clear) instead of normal anchor lights.
At anchor, shows only standard anchor lights plus the red-white-red vertical lights, without the red and green obstruction lights.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel engaged in underwater operations, when restricted in her ability to manoeuvre, underway and an obstruction exists on her port side Time of the day: Daytime
rule_refs: Rule 27 (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre)

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 27(d), a vessel engaged in underwater operations, when restricted in her ability to manoeuvre, shall exhibit shapes prescribed in Rule 27(b)(ii) and shall in addition, when an obstruction exists, exhibit: (i) two balls in a vertical line to indicate the side on which the obstruction exists; (ii) two diamonds in a vertical line to indicate the side on which another vessel may pass. According to Rule 27(b)(ii), shall exhibit three shapes in a vertical line where they can best be seen. The highest and lowest of these shapes shall be balls and the middle one a diamond.
Shows ball-diamond-ball in vertical line, plus two balls on port side (obstruction) and two diamonds on starboard side (clear).
During daytime, only the ball-diamond-ball shapes are shown without any additional shapes for obstruction indication.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel engaged in underwater operations, when restricted in her ability to manoeuvre, at anchor and an obstruction exists on her port side Time of the day: Daytime
rule_refs: Rule 27 (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre)

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 27(d), a vessel engaged in underwater operations, when restricted in her ability to manoeuvre, shall exhibit shapes prescribed in Rule 27(b)(ii) and shall in addition, when an obstruction exists, exhibit: (iii) when at anchor, shapes prescribed in subparagraphs (i) and (ii) instead of shapes prescribed in Rule 30; (i) two balls in a vertical line to indicate the side on which the obstruction exists; (ii) two diamonds in a vertical line to indicate the side on which another vessel may pass. According to Rule 27(b)(ii), shall exhibit three shapes in a vertical line where they can best be seen. The highest and lowest of these shapes shall be balls and the middle one a diamond.
At anchor during daytime, shows ball-diamond-ball in vertical line, plus two balls on port side (obstruction) and two diamonds on starboard side (clear) instead of anchor ball.
Shows only the anchor ball shape; the ball-diamond-ball and obstruction shapes are not required when at anchor.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel engaged in diving operations not making way through the water Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
rule_refs: Rule 27 (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre)

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 27(e)(i), whenever the size of a vessel engaged in diving operations makes it impracticable to exhibit all the lights prescribed in Rule 27(d), three all-round lights in a vertical line where they can best be seen shall be exhibited. The highest and lowest of these lights shall be red and the middle light shall be white.
Small diving vessels show simplified lights: three all-round lights in vertical line, red-white-red.
Small diving vessels are exempt from all light requirements and may show only a white all-round light.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel engaged in diving operations Time of the day: Daytime
rule_refs: Rule 27 (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre)

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 27(e)(ii), whenever the size of a vessel engaged in diving operations makes it impracticable to exhibit all shapes prescribed in Rule 27(d), a rigid replica of the International Code flag "A" not less than 1 metre in height shall be exhibited. Measures shall be taken to ensure its all-round visibility.
Small diving vessels display International Code flag A replica at least 1 meter high, ensuring all-round visibility.
Small diving vessels show three balls in vertical line instead of the flag A replica.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel engaged in mine clearance operations of more than 50 m in length underway Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
rule_refs: Rule 27 (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre)

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 27(f), a vessel engaged in mine clearance operations shall in addition to the lights prescribed for a power-driven vessel in Rule 23, exhibit three all-round green lights. One of these lights shall be exhibited near the foremast head and one at each end of the fore yard. These lights indicate that it is dangerous for another vessel to approach within 1000 m of the mine clearance vessel. According to Rule 23(a), a power-driven vessel underway shall exhibit: (i) a masthead light forward; (ii) a second masthead light abaft of and higher than the forward one; (iii) sidelights; (iv) a sternlight.
Shows normal power-driven vessel lights (two masthead lights, sidelights, sternlight) plus three green all-round lights: one near foremast head and one at each end of fore yard.
Shows only three green all-round lights without the standard power-driven vessel lights.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel engaged in mine clearance operations of more than 50 m in length but less than 100 m in length at anchor Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
rule_refs: Rule 27 (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre)

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 27(f), a vessel engaged in mine clearance operations shall in addition to the lights prescribed for a vessel at anchor in Rule 30, exhibit three all-round green lights. One of these lights shall be exhibited near the foremast head and one at each end of the fore yard. These lights indicate that it is dangerous for another vessel to approach within 1000 m of the mine clearance vessel. According to Rule 30(a), a vessel at anchor shall exhibit: (i) in the fore part, an all-round white light; (ii) at or near the stern and at a lower level, an all-round white light.
Shows anchor lights (white light fore and aft) plus three green all-round lights: one near foremast head and one at each end of fore yard.
At anchor, mine clearance vessels show only the three green lights without anchor lights.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel engaged in mine clearance operations of more than 50 m in length underway Time of the day: Daytime
rule_refs: Rule 27 (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre)

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 27(f), a vessel engaged in mine clearance operations shall exhibit three balls. One of these shapes shall be exhibited near the foremast head and one at each end of the fore yard. These shapes indicate that it is dangerous for another vessel to approach within 1000 m of the mine clearance vessel.
Shows three balls: one near foremast head and one at each end of fore yard to indicate keep clear 1000 meters.
Mine clearance vessels show three balls in vertical line to indicate restricted manoeuvrability.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel engaged in mine clearance operations at anchor Time of the day: Daytime
rule_refs: Rule 27 (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre)

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 27(f), a vessel engaged in mine clearance operations shall in addition to the shapes prescribed for a vessel at anchor in Rule 30, exhibit three balls. One of these shapes shall be exhibited near the foremast head and one at each end of the fore yard. These shapes indicate that it is dangerous for another vessel to approach within 1000 m of the mine clearance vessel. According to Rule 30(a), a vessel at anchor shall exhibit where it can best be seen: (i) in the fore part, one ball.
At anchor shows anchor ball in fore part plus three balls: one near foremast head and one at each end of fore yard.
Shows only the three balls for mine clearance without the anchor ball.

scenario: Type of vessel: Power-driven vessel of less than 50 m in length underway Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 23(a), a power-driven vessel underway shall exhibit: (i) a masthead light forward; (iii) sidelights; (iv) a sternlight. According to Rule 23(a)(ii), a power-driven vessel of less than 50 m in length shall not be obliged to exhibit a second masthead light abaft of and higher than the forward one but may do so.
Shows one masthead light forward, sidelights and sternlight. May optionally show a second masthead light but not required for vessels under 50 meters.
Must show two masthead lights in vertical line, sidelights and sternlight regardless of length.

scenario: Type of vessel: Power-driven vessel of more than 50 m in length underway Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 23(a), a power-driven vessel underway, shall exhibit: (i) a masthead light forward; (ii) a second masthead light abaft of and higher than the forward one; (iii) sidelights; (iv) a sternlight.
Vessels over 50 meters must show two masthead lights, sidelights and sternlight.
Shows one masthead light, sidelights and sternlight; the second masthead light is optional.

scenario: Type of vessel: Power-driven vessel of less than 12 m in length underway Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 23(d)(i), a power-driven vessel of less than 12 m in length may in lieu of the lights prescribed in Rule 23(a) exhibit: an all-round white light and sidelights.
May show an all-round white light and sidelights instead of masthead light and sternlight.
Must show standard masthead light, sidelights and sternlight like all power-driven vessels.

scenario: Type of vessel: Power-driven vessel of less than 7 m in length whose maximum speed does not exceed 7 knots underway Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 23(d)(ii), a power-driven vessel of less than 7 m in length whose maximum speed does not exceed 7 knots may in lieu of the lights prescribed in Rule 23(a) exhibit: an all-round white light and shall, if practicable, also exhibit sidelights.
May show one all-round white light and should show sidelights if practicable.
Must show masthead light, sidelights and sternlight regardless of size or speed.

scenario: Type of vessel: Power-driven vessel of less than 12 m in length underway Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 23(d)(iii), the masthead light or all-round white light on a power driven vessel of less than 12 m in length may be displaced from the fore and aft centerline of the vessel if centerline fitting is not practicable, provided the sidelights are combined in one lantern which shall be carried on the fore and aft centerline of the vessel or located as nearly as practicable in the same fore and aft line as the masthead light or all-round white light.
The masthead or all-round white light may be off-centerline if necessary, but sidelights must be combined in one lantern on centerline or in same fore-aft line as the masthead light.
All lights must be on the centerline of the vessel regardless of vessel size.

scenario: Type of vessel: Sailing vessel underway Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
rule_refs: Rule 25 (Sailings vessels underway and vessels under oars)

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 25(a), a sailing vessel underway shall exhibit: (i) sidelights; (ii) a sternlight.
Sailing vessels show sidelights and sternlight.
Sailing vessels show masthead light, sidelights and sternlight like power-driven vessels.

scenario: Type of vessel: Sailing vessel underway Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
rule_refs: Rule 25 (Sailings vessels underway and vessels under oars)

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 25(c), a sailing vessel underway may, in addition to the lights prescribed in Rule 25(a) exhibit at or near the top of the mast, where they can best be seen, two all-round lights in a vertical line, the upper being red and the lower green, but these lights shall not be exhibited in conjunction with the combined lantern permitted by Rule 25(b).
May optionally show two all-round lights at masthead (red over green) in addition to sidelights and sternlight, but not with combined lantern.
Must show red over green lights at masthead in addition to all other navigation lights.

scenario: Type of vessel: Sailing vessel of less than 20 m in length underway Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
rule_refs: Rule 25 (Sailings vessels underway and vessels under oars)

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 25(b), in a sailing vessel underway of less than 20 metres in length the lights prescribed in Rule 25(a) may be combined in one lantern at or near the top of the mast where it can best be seen.
Sailing vessels under 20 meters may combine sidelights and sternlight in one tricolor lantern at the masthead.
All sailing vessels regardless of size must show separate sidelights and sternlight.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel proceeding under sail when also being propelled by machinery Time of the day: Daytime
rule_refs: Rule 25 (Sailings vessels underway and vessels under oars)

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 25(e), a vessel proceeding under sail when also being propelled by machinery shall exhibit forward where it can best be seen a conical shape, apex downwards.
When under sail and engine, must show a cone apex down forward.
No shape is required; the vessel displays lights for a power-driven vessel.

scenario: Type of vessel: Sailing vessel of less than 7 m in legth underway Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
rule_refs: Rule 25 (Sailings vessels underway and vessels under oars)

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 25(d)(i), a sailing vessel underway of less than 7 m in length shall, if practicable, exhibit the lights prescribed in Rule 25(a) or (b), but if she does not, she shall have ready to hand an electric torch or lighted lantern showing a white light which shall be exhibited in sufficient time to prevent a collision.
Should show navigation lights if practicable, otherwise must have a white light ready to show in time to prevent collision.
Is completely exempt from all light requirements.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel under oars Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
rule_refs: Rule 25 (Sailings vessels underway and vessels under oars)

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 25(d)(ii), a vessel under oars may exhibit the lights prescribed in Rule 25 for sailing vessels, but if she does not, she may have ready at hand an electric torch or lighted lantern showing a white light which shall be exhibited in sufficient time to prevent collision.
May show sailing vessel lights or alternatively have a white light ready to show to prevent collision.
Must show sidelights and sternlight at all times.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel engaged in trawling when making way through the water Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 26(a), a vessel engaged in fishing, whether underway or at anchor, shall exhibit only the lights and shapes prescribed in Rule 26. According to Rule 26(b), a vessel when engaged in trawling shall exhibit: (i) two all-round lights in a vertical line, the upper being green and the lower white; (ii) a masthead light abaft of and higher that the all-round green light; (iii) sidelights and a sternlight. Per Rule 26(b)(ii), a vessel of less than 50 metres in length shall not be obliged to exhibit a masthead light but may do so.
Shows green over white all-round lights, masthead light (if 50m or more), sidelights and sternlight when making way.
Shows red over white all-round lights to indicate fishing operations.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel engaged in trawling when not making way through the water Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 26(a), a vessel engaged in fishing, whether underway or at anchor, shall exhibit only the lights and shapes prescribed in Rule 26. According to Rule 26(b), a vessel when engaged in trawling shall exhibit: (i) two all-round lights in a vertical line, the upper being green and the lower white; (ii) a masthead light abaft of and higher that the all-round green light. Per Rule 26(b)(ii), a vessel of less than 50 m in length shall not be obliged to exhibit a masthead light but may do so.
Not making way shows green over white all-round lights and masthead light if 50 meters or more.
Must show sidelights and sternlight even when not making way through the water.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel engaged in trawling Time of the day: Daytime

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 26(a), a vessel engaged in fishing, whether underway or at anchor, shall exhibit only the lights and shapes prescribed in Rule 26. According to Rule 26(b), a vessel when engaged in trawling shall exhibit: (i) a shape consisting of two cones with their apexes together in a vertical line one above the other.
Shows two cones with apexes together in vertical line during daytime.
Shows two balls in vertical line to indicate fishing operations.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel engaged in fishing, other than trawling when making way through the water (when the outlying gear does not extend more than 150 m horizontally from the vessel) Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 26(a), a vessel engaged in fishing, whether underway or at anchor, shall exhibit only the lights and shapes prescribed in Rule 26. According to Rule 26(c), a vessel engaged in fishing, other than trawling, shall exhibit: (i) two all-round lights in a vertical line, the upper being red and the lower white; (iii) sidelights and a sternlight.
Fishing other than trawling, making way, shows red over white all-round lights, sidelights and sternlight.
Shows green over white lights like trawling vessels.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel engaged in fishing, other than trawling not making way through the water (when the outlying gear does not extend more than 150 m horizontally from the vessel) Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 26(a), a vessel engaged in fishing, whether underway or at anchor, shall exhibit only the lights and shapes prescribed in Rule 26. According to Rule 26(c), a vessel engaged in fishing, other than trawling, shall exhibit: (i) two all-round lights in a vertical line, the upper being red and the lower white.
Not making way, shows red over white all-round lights only.
Must also show sidelights and sternlight even when not making way.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel engaged in fishing, other than trawling (when the outlying gear does not extend more than 150 metres horizontally from the vessel) Time of the day: Daytime

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 26(a), a vessel engaged in fishing, whether underway or at anchor, shall exhibit only the lights and shapes prescribed in Rule 26. According to Rule 26(c), a vessel engaged in fishing, other than trawling, shall exhibit: (i) a shape consisting of two cones with their apexes together in a vertical line one above the other.
Shows two cones apex to apex in vertical line.
Shows one cone apex up to indicate fishing operations.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel engaged in fishing, other than trawling when there is outlying gear extending more than 150 m horizontally from the vessel Time of the day: Daytime

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 26(a), a vessel engaged in fishing, whether underway or at anchor, shall exhibit only the lights and shapes prescribed in Rule 26. According to Rule 26(c), a vessel engaged in fishing, other than trawling, shall exhibit: (i) a shape consisting of two cones with their apexes together in a vertical line one above the other; (ii) a cone apex upwards in the direction of the outlying gear.
