Shows two cones apex to apex in vertical line plus one cone apex up pointing toward the outlying gear.
Shows only the two cones apex to apex; no additional cone is required for outlying gear.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel engaged in fishing, other than trawling when there is outlying gear extending more than 150 m horizontally from the vessel, when not making way through the water Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 26(a), a vessel engaged in fishing, whether underway or at anchor, shall exhibit only the lights and shapes prescribed in Rule 26. According to Rule 26(c), a vessel engaged in fishing, other than trawling, shall exhibit: (i) two all-round lights in a vertical line, the upper being red and the lower white; (ii) an all-round white light in the direction of the outlying gear.
Not making way with gear over 150m shows red over white lights plus white light in direction of gear.
Shows only red over white lights without additional white light for outlying gear.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel engaged in fishing, other than trawling when there is outlying gear extending more than 150 m horizontally from the vessel when making way thorugh the water Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 26(a), a vessel engaged in fishing, whether underway or at anchor, shall exhibit only the lights and shapes prescribed in Rule 26. According to Rule 26(c), a vessel engaged in fishing, other than trawling, shall exhibit: (i) two all-round lights in a vertical line, the upper being red and the lower white; (ii) an all-round white light in the direction of the outlying gear; (iii) sidelights and a sternlight.
Making way with gear over 150m shows red over white lights, white light toward gear, plus sidelights and sternlight.
Shows the same lights whether making way or not, without sidelights and sternlight.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel constrained by her draught of less than 50 m in length underway Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 28, a vessel constrained by her draught may, in addition to the lights prescribed for power-driven vessels in Rule 23, exhibit where they can best be seen three all-round red lights in a vertical line. According to Rule 23(a), a power-driven vessel underway shall exhibit: (i) a masthead light forward; (iii) sidelights; (iv) a sternlight. Per Rule 23(a)(ii), a power-driven vessel of less than 50 m in length shall not be obliged to exhibit a second masthead light abaft of and higher than the forward one but may do so.
Shows masthead light, sidelights, sternlight, and may optionally show three red all-round lights in vertical line. Second masthead light optional for vessels under 50m.
Must show three red lights in vertical line instead of normal navigation lights.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel constrained by her draught of more than 50 m in length underway Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 28, a vessel constrained by her draught may, in addition to the lights prescribed for power-driven vessels in Rule 23, exhibit where they can best be seen three all-round red lights in a vertical line. According to Rule 23(a), a power-driven vessel underway shall exhibit: (i) a masthead light forward; (ii) a second masthead light abaft of and higher than the forward one; (iii) sidelights; (iv) a sternlight.
Shows two masthead lights, sidelights, sternlight, and may optionally show three red all-round lights in vertical line.
Shows only three red lights in vertical line without power-driven vessel lights.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel constrained by her draught underway Time of the day: Daytime

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 28, a vessel constrained by her draught may exhibit where it can best be seen a cylinder.
May optionally display a cylinder shape during daytime.
Must display three balls in vertical line to indicate constrained by draught.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel engaged on pilotage duty underway Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 29(a), a vessel engaged on pilotage duty shall exhibit: (i) at or near the masthead, two all-round lights in a vertical line, the upper being white and the lower red; (ii) sidelights and a sternlight.
Shows white over red all-round lights at masthead, plus sidelights and sternlight.
Shows red over white all-round lights to indicate pilot vessel status.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel engaged on pilotage duty of less than 50 m in length at anchor Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 29(a), a vessel engaged on pilotage duty shall exhibit: (i) at or near the masthead, two all-round lights in a vertical line, the upper being white and the lower red; (iii) the lights prescribed in Rule 30 for vessels at anchor. According to Rule 30(b), a vessel of less than 50 m in length may exhibit an all-round white light where it can best be seen instead of the lights prescribed in Rule 30(a).
Shows white over red lights at masthead plus anchor light (single white light for vessels under 50m).
At anchor shows only the white over red pilot lights without anchor lights.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel of less than 50 m in length at anchor Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 30(b), a vessel of less than 50 m in length may exhibit an all-round white light where it can best be seen instead of the lights prescribed in Rule 30(a).
May show one all-round white light instead of separate fore and aft anchor lights.
Must show two white lights, one forward and one aft, regardless of length.

scenario: Area: All areas but not in or near a narrow channel, fairway or anchorage, or where other vessels normally navigate Type of vessel: Vessel of less than 7 m in length at anchor Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 30(e), a vessel of less than 7 m in length, when at anchor, not in or near a narrow channel, fairway or anchorage, or where other vessels normally navigate, shall not be required to exhibit the lights prescribed in Rule 30(a) and Rule 30(b).
Vessels under 7m at anchor outside traffic areas are not required to show anchor lights.
All vessels must show anchor lights regardless of size or location.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel at anchor of more than 50 m in length but less than 100 m in length Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 30(a), a vessel at anchor shall exhibit where it can best be seen: (i) in the fore part, an all-round white light; (ii) at or near the stern and at a lower level that the light prescribed in subparagraph (i), an all-round white light.
Shows one white light forward and one white light aft at lower level.
Shows one white light only since vessel is less than 100 meters.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel of 100 m and more in length at anchor Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 30(a), a vessel at anchor shall exhibit where it can best be seen: (i) in the fore part, an all-round white light; (ii) at or near the stern and at a lower level that the light prescribed in subparagraph (i), an all-round white light. According to Rule 30(c), a vessel of 100 m and more in length at anchor shall, also use the available working or equivalent lights to illuminate her decks.
Shows white light forward and aft, plus deck illumination for vessels 100m or more.
Shows the same anchor lights as smaller vessels without deck illumination requirement.

scenario: Area: All areas but not in or near a narrow channel, fairway or anchorage, or where other vessels normally navigate Type of vessel: Vessel of less than 7 m in length at anchor Time of the day: Daytime

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 30(e), a vessel of less than 7 m in length, when at anchor, not in or near a narrow channel, fairway or anchorage, or where other vessels normally navigate, shall not be required to exhibit shape prescribed in Rule 30(a)(i).
Vessels under 7m at anchor outside traffic areas are not required to show anchor ball.
All vessels must display anchor ball during daytime regardless of size.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel at anchor Time of the day: Daytime

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 30(a), a vessel at anchor shall exhibit where it can best be seen: (i) in the fore part, one ball.
Displays one ball in the forward part during daytime.
Displays two balls in vertical line to indicate anchored status.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel aground Time of the day: Daytime

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 30(d), a vessel aground shall exhibit, where they can best be seen: (ii) three balls in a vertical line.
Shows three balls in vertical line during daytime.
Shows one ball like an anchored vessel.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel of less than 12 m in length aground Time of the day: Daytime

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 30(f), a vessel of less than 12 m in length, when aground, shall not be required to exhibit the shapes prescribed in Rule 30(d)(ii).
Vessels under 12m aground are not required to show three balls.
Must show three balls in vertical line regardless of vessel size.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel of less than 50 m aground Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 30(d), a vessel aground shall exhibit the lights prescribed in Rule 30(b) and in addition, where they can best be seen: (i) two all-round red lights in a vertical line.
Shows anchor light (single white for vessels under 50m) plus two red lights in vertical line.
Shows only two red lights in vertical line without anchor lights.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel of more than 50 m in length aground Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 30(d), a vessel aground shall exhibit the lights prescribed in Rule 30(a) and in addition, where they can best be seen: (i) two all-round red lights in a vertical line.
Shows white lights fore and aft (anchor lights) plus two red lights in vertical line.
Shows three red lights in vertical line without anchor lights.

scenario: Visibility: Good Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 20(b), the rules concerning lights shall be complied with from sunset to sunrise, and during such times no other lights shall be exhibited, except such lights as cannot be mistaken for the lights specified in these Rules or do not impair their visibility or distinctive character, or interfere with the keeping of a proper look-out. According to Rule 20(e), the lights specified in these Rules shall comply with the provisions of Annex 1 to these Regulations.
Lights must be shown from sunset to sunrise and must comply with Annex 1. No other lights that could be confused with navigation lights should be shown.
Vessels may show any lights they wish as long as navigation lights are also displayed.

scenario: Time of the day: Daytime

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 20(d), the rules concerning shapes shall be complied with by day.
Shapes must be displayed during daytime hours (sunrise to sunset).
Shapes must be displayed at all times, both day and night.

scenario: Visibility: Restricted Time of the day: From sunrise to sunset

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 20(c), the lights prescribed by these Rules shall, if carried, also be exhibited from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility and may be exhibited in all other circumstances when it is deemed necessary. According to Rule 20(e), the lights specified in these Rules shall comply with the provisions of Annex 1 to these Regulations.
Navigation lights should be displayed during daytime in restricted visibility.
Lights are only required from sunset to sunrise, never during daytime even in restricted visibility.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel engaged in fishing in close proximity to other vessels engaged in fishing

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 26(a), a vessel engaged in fishing, whether underway or at anchor, shall exhibit only the lights and shapes prescribed in Rule 26. According to Rule 26(d), a vessel engaged in fishing in close proximity to other vessel engaged in fishing may exhibit the additional signals described in Annex II to these Regulations.
May show additional signals from Annex II when fishing in close proximity to other fishing vessels.
Must show additional signals whenever engaged in fishing operations.

scenario: Type of vessel: Fishing vessel not engaged in fishing

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 26(e), a vessel when not engaged in fishing shall not exhibit the lights or shapes prescribed in Rule 26, but only those prescribed for a vessel of her length.
When not fishing, shows lights for a vessel of her length, not fishing vessel lights.
Must continue to show fishing vessel lights at all times since it is a fishing vessel.

scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel underway, when manoeuvring Vessels are in sight of one another

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 34(a), a vessel altering its course to starboard shall indicate that manoeuvre by one short blast on her whistle. According to Rule 34(b)(i), a vessel altering its course to starboard may supplement the whistle signals prescribed in Rule 34(a) by light signals and indicate that manoeuvre by one flash. Per Rule 34(b)(ii), the duration of flash shall be about one second and the interval between successive signals shall be not less that ten seconds. In accordance with Rule 34(b)(iii), the light used for this signal shall, if fitted, be an all-round white light, visible at a minimum range of 5 miles. Per Rule 34(f), if whistles are fitted on a vessel at a distance apart of more than 100 m, one whistle only shall be used for giving manoeuvring and warning signals.
Sounds one short blast when altering to starboard, may supplement with one flash of white light.
Sounds two short blasts when altering to starboard.

scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel underway, when manoeuvring Vessels are in sight of one another

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 34(a), a vessel altering its course to starboard shall indicate that manoeuvre by one short blast on her whistle. According to Rule 34(f), if whistles are fitted on a vessel at a distance apart of more than 100 m, one whistle only shall be used for giving manoeuvring and warning signals.
Sounds one short blast for altering course to starboard.
No sound signal is required when altering course in sight of other vessels.

scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel underway, when manoeuvring Vessels are in sight of one another

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 34(a), a vessel altering its course to port shall indicate that manoeuvre by two short blasts on her whistle. According to Rule 34(b)(i), a vessel altering its course to port may supplement the whistle signals prescribed in Rule 34(a) by light signals and indicate that manoeuvre by two flashes. Per Rule 34(b)(ii), the duration of each flash shall be about one second, the interval between flashes shall be about one second, and the interval between successive signals shall be not less that ten seconds. In accordance with Rule 34(b)(iii), the light used for this signal shall, if fitted, be an all-round white light, visible at a minimum range of 5 miles. Per Rule 34(f), if whistles are fitted on a vessel at a distance apart of more than 100 m, one whistle only shall be used for giving manoeuvring and warning signals.
Sounds two short blasts when altering to port, may supplement with two flashes of white light.
Sounds one short blast when altering to port.

scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel underway, when manoeuvring Vessels are in sight of one another

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 34(a), a vessel altering its course to port shall indicate that manoeuvre by two short blasts on her whistle. According to Rule 34(f), if whistles are fitted on a vessel at a distance apart of more than 100 m, one whistle only shall be used for giving manoeuvring and warning signals.
Sounds two short blasts for altering course to port.
Sounds three short blasts for altering course to port.

scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel underway, when manoeuvring Vessels are in sight of one another

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 34(a), a vessel operating astern propulsion shall indicate that manoeuvre by three short blasts on her whistle. According to Rule 34(b)(i), a vessel operating astern propulsion may supplement the whistle signals prescribed in Rule 34(a) by light signals and indicate that manoeuvre by three flashes. Per Rule 34(b)(ii), the duration of each flash shall be about one second, the interval between flashes shall be about one second, and the interval between successive signals shall be not less that ten seconds. In accordance with Rule 34(b)(iii), the light used for this signal shall, if fitted, be an all-round white light, visible at a minimum range of 5 miles. Per Rule 34(f), if whistles are fitted on a vessel at a distance apart of more than 100 m, one whistle only shall be used for giving manoeuvring and warning signals.
Sounds three short blasts when operating astern propulsion, may supplement with three flashes.
Sounds one prolonged blast when going astern.

scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel underway, when manoeuvring Vessels are in sight of one another

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 34(a), a vessel operating astern propulsion shall indicate that manoeuvre by three short blasts on her whistle. According to Rule 34(f), if whistles are fitted on a vessel at a distance apart of more than 100 m, one whistle only shall be used for giving manoeuvring and warning signals.
Sounds three short blasts when operating astern propulsion.
Sounds two short blasts when going astern.

scenario: Vessel A fails to understand the intentions or actions of vessel B Vessels are in sight of one another

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 34(d), when vessels in sight of one another are approaching each other and from any cause either vessel fails to understand the intentions or actions of the other vessel, or is in doubt whether sufficient action is being taken by the other to avoid collision, the vessel in doubt shall immediately indicate such doubt by giving at least five short and rapid blasts on the whistle. According to Rule 34(f), if whistles are fitted on a vessel at a distance apart of more than 100 m, one whistle only shall be used for giving manoeuvring and warning signals.
Vessel A should sound at least five short and rapid blasts to indicate doubt about vessel B's intentions or actions.
Vessel A should sound one prolonged blast to warn vessel B of the uncertainty.

scenario: Vessel A fails to understand the intentions or actions of vessel B Vessels are in sight of one another

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 34(d), when vessels in sight of one another are approaching each other and from any cause either vessel fails to understand the intentions or actions of the other vessel, or is in doubt whether sufficient action is being taken by the other to avoid collision, the vessel in doubt shall immediately indicate such doubt by giving at least five short and rapid blasts on the whistle. According to Rule 34(d), sound signals may be supplemented by a light signal of at least five short and rapid flashes. Per Rule 34(f), if whistles are fitted on a vessel at a distance apart of more than 100 m, one whistle only shall be used for giving manoeuvring and warning signals.
Sounds at least five short and rapid blasts, may supplement with at least five short and rapid flashes.
Sounds three short blasts to indicate doubt about the other vessel's actions.

scenario: Area: Near a bend or an area of a channel or a fairway where other vessel may be obscured by an intervening obstruction

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 34(e), a vessel nearing a bend or an area of the channel of fairway where other vessels may be obscured by an intervening obstruction shall sound one prolonged blast. Such signal shall be answered with a prolonged blast by any approaching vessel that may be within hearing around the bend or behind the intervening obstruction. According to Rule 34(f), if whistles are fitted on a vessel at a distance apart of more than 100 m, one whistle only shall be used for giving manoeuvring and warning signals.
Sounds one prolonged blast when nearing a bend with obstruction. Any approaching vessel should answer with one prolonged blast.
Sounds five short blasts to warn of the blind bend ahead.

scenario: Type of vessel: Power-driven vessel making way through the water Visibility: In or near an area of restricted visibility, weather by day or night

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 35(a), a power-driven vessel making way through the water shall sound at intervals of not more than 2 minutes one prolonged blast.
Sounds one prolonged blast at intervals not exceeding 2 minutes.
Sounds two prolonged blasts at intervals not exceeding 2 minutes.

scenario: Type of vessel: Power-driven vessel underway but stopped and making no way through the water Visibility: In or near an area of restricted visibility, weather by day or night

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 35(b), a power-driven vessel underway but stopped and making no way through the water shall sound at intervals of not more than 2 minutes two prolonged blasts in succession with an interval of about 2 seconds between them.
Sounds two prolonged blasts with 2 second interval between them, at intervals not exceeding 2 minutes.
Sounds one prolonged blast like a vessel making way.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel not under command Visibility: In or near an area of restricted visibility, weather by day or night

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 35(c), a vessel not under command shall, instead of the signals prescribed in Rule 35(a) or (b), sound at intervals of not more that 2 minutes three blasts in succession, namely one prolonged followed by two short blasts.
Sounds one prolonged and two short blasts at intervals not exceeding 2 minutes.
Sounds two prolonged blasts like a stopped power-driven vessel.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre Visibility: In or near an area of restricted visibility, weather by day or night

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 35(c), a vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre shall, instead of the signals prescribed in Rule 35(a) or (b), sound at intervals of not more that 2 minutes three blasts in succession, namely one prolonged followed by two short blasts.
Sounds one prolonged and two short blasts at intervals not exceeding 2 minutes.
Sounds three prolonged blasts at intervals not exceeding 2 minutes.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel constrained by her draught Visibility: In or near an area of restricted visibility, weather by day or night

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 35(c), a vessel constrained by her draught shall, instead of the signals prescribed in Rule 35(a) or (b), sound at intervals of not more that 2 minutes three blasts in succession, namely one prolonged followed by two short blasts.
Sounds one prolonged and two short blasts at intervals not exceeding 2 minutes.
Sounds four short blasts to indicate constrained by draught.

scenario: Type of vessel: Sailing vessel Visibility: In or near an area of restricted visibility, weather by day or night

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 35(c), a sailing vessel shall, instead of the signals prescribed in Rule 35(a) or (b), sound at intervals of not more that 2 minutes three blasts in succession, namely one prolonged followed by two short blasts.
Sounds one prolonged and two short blasts at intervals not exceeding 2 minutes.
Sounds one prolonged blast like a power-driven vessel making way.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel engaged in fishing Visibility: In or near an area of restricted visibility, weather by day or night

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 35(c), a vessel engaged in fishing shall, instead of the signals prescribed in Rule 35(a) or (b), sound at intervals of not more that 2 minutes three blasts in succession, namely one prolonged followed by two short blasts.
Sounds one prolonged and two short blasts at intervals not exceeding 2 minutes.
Sounds five short blasts to indicate engaged in fishing.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel engaged in fishing, when at anchor Visibility: In or near an area of restricted visibility, weather by day or night

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 35(d), a vessel engaged in fishing, when at anchor, shall instead of the signals prescribed in Rule 35(g) sound the signal prescribed in Rule 35(c).
At anchor, fishing vessel sounds one prolonged and two short blasts at intervals not exceeding 2 minutes instead of bell.
At anchor, sounds rapid bell ringing like any anchored vessel.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre when carrying out her work at anchor Visibility: In or near an area of restricted visibility, weather by day or night

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 35(d), a vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre when carrying out her work at anchor shall instead of the signals prescribed in Rule 35(g) sound the signal prescribed in Rule 35(c).
At anchor carrying out work, sounds one prolonged and two short blasts at intervals not exceeding 2 minutes instead of bell.
Sounds bell rapidly for 5 seconds like other anchored vessels.

scenario: Type of vessel: Towing vessel and vessel being towed Visibility: In or near an area of restricted visibility, weather by day or night

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 35(c), a vessel engaged in towing another vessel shall, instead of the signals prescribed in Rule 35(a) or (b), sound at intervals of not more that 2 minutes three blasts in succession, namely one prolonged followed by two short blasts. According to Rule 35(e), a vessel towed or if more that one vessel is towed the last vessel of the tow, if manned, shall at intervals of not more than 2 minutes sound four blasts in succession, namely one prolonged blast followed by three short blasts. When practicable, this signal shall be made immediately after the signal made by the towing vessel.
Towing vessel sounds one prolonged and two short. Vessel being towed (if manned) sounds one prolonged and three short, preferably immediately after towing vessel signal.
Both vessels sound one prolonged blast at the same time.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel at anchor of less than 100 m in length Visibility: In or near an area of restricted visibility, weather by day or night

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 35(g), a vessel at anchor shall at intervals of not more than one minute ring the bell rapidly for about 5 seconds. According to Rule 35(g), a vessel at anchor may in addition sound three blasts in succession, namely one short, one prolonged and one short blast, to give warning of her position and of the possibility of collision to an approaching vessel.
Rings bell rapidly for about 5 seconds at intervals not exceeding 1 minute. May also sound one short, one prolonged, one short blast.
Sounds two prolonged blasts at 2 minute intervals like a stopped vessel.

scenario: Type of vessel: Pushing vessel and vessel being pushed ahead rigidly connected in a composited unit making way through the water Visibility: In or near an area of restricted visibility, weather by day or night

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 35(f), when a pushing vessel and a vessel being pushed ahead are rigidly connected in a composite unit they shall be regarded as a power-driven vessel and shall give the signals prescribed in Rule 35(a).
When rigidly connected as composite unit making way, sounds one prolonged blast at intervals not exceeding 2 minutes.
Pushing vessel sounds one prolonged and two short, vessel being pushed sounds one prolonged and three short.

scenario: Type of vessel: Pushing vessel and vessel being pushed ahead rigidly connected in a composite unit underway but stopped and making no way through the water Visibility: In or near an area of restricted visibility, weather by day or night

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 35(f), when a pushing vessel and a vessel being pushed ahead are rigidly connected in a composite unit they shall be regarded as a power-driven vessel and shall give the signals prescribed in Rule 35(b).
When rigidly connected as composite unit stopped and making no way, sounds two prolonged blasts with 2 second interval, at intervals not exceeding 2 minutes.
Sounds one prolonged blast like a vessel making way.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel at anchor of 100 m or more in length Visibility: In or near an area of restricted visibility, weather by day or night

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 35(g), a vessel at anchor shall at intervals of not more than one minute ring the bell rapidly for about 5 seconds. According to Rule 35(g), in a vessel of 100 metres of more in length the bell shall be sounded in the forepart of the vessel and immediately after the ringing of the bell the gong shall be sounded rapidly for about 5 seconds in the after part of the vessel. Per Rule 35(g), a vessel at anchor may in addition sound three short blasts in succession, namely one short, one prolonged and one short blast, to give warning of her position and of the possibility of collision to an approaching vessel.
Rings bell forward for 5 seconds then gong aft for 5 seconds at intervals not exceeding 1 minute. May also sound one short, one prolonged, one short.
Rings bell only, same as vessels under 100 meters.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel aground of less than 100 m in length Visibility: In or near an area of restricted visibility, weather by day or night

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 35(h), a vessel aground shall give the bell signal prescribed in Rule 35(g) and shall, in addition, give three separate and distinct strokes on the bell immediately before and after the rapid ringing of the bell. According to Rule 35(h), a vessel aground may in addition sound an appropriate whistle signal.
Sounds three bell strokes, then rapid bell for 5 seconds, then three bell strokes, at intervals not exceeding 1 minute. May add whistle signal.
Sounds only rapid bell ringing like an anchored vessel.

scenario: Vessel aground of 100 m or more in length Visibility: In or near an area of restricted visibility, weather by day or night

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 35(h), a vessel aground shall give the bell signal and the gong signal prescribed in Rule 35(g) and shall, in addition, give three separate and distinct strokes on the bell immediately before and after the rapid ringing of the bell. According to Rule 35(h), a vessel aground may in addition sound an appropriate whistle signal.
Sounds three bell strokes, rapid bell forward for 5 seconds, three bell strokes, then gong aft for 5 seconds, at intervals not exceeding 1 minute. May add whistle.
Sounds bell and gong like anchored vessel without three separate strokes.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel of 12 m or more but less than 20 m in length at anchor Visibility: In or near an area of restricted visibility, weather by day or night

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 35(i), a vessel of 12 m or more but less than 20 m in length shall not be obliged to give the bell signals prescribed in Rule 35(g). However, if she does not, she shall make some other efficient sound signal at intervals of not more than 2 minutes.
Not required to ring bell but must make some other efficient sound signal at intervals not exceeding 2 minutes.
Must ring bell like larger vessels at intervals not exceeding 1 minute.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel of less than 12 m in length Visibility: In or near an area of restricted visibility, weather by day or night

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 35(j), a vessel of less than 12 m in length shall not be obliged to give the signals prescribed in Rule 35(a), (b), (c), (d), (e), (f), (g) and (h) but, if she does not, shall make some other efficient sound signal at intervals of not more that 2 minutes.
Not required to give prescribed fog signals but must make some other efficient sound signal at intervals not exceeding 2 minutes.
Completely exempt from all sound signal requirements in restricted visibility.

scenario: Type of vessel: Pilot vessel engaged on pilotage duty making way through the water Visibility: In or near an area of restricted visibility, weather by day or night

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 35(k), a pilot vessel when engaged on pilotage duty may in addition to the signals prescribed in Rule 35(a) sound an identity signal consisting of four short blasts.
Sounds one prolonged blast at intervals not exceeding 2 minutes, may additionally sound four short blasts as identity signal.
Must sound four short blasts instead of one prolonged blast.

scenario: Type of vessel: Pilot vessel engaged on pilotage duty underway but stopped and making no way through the water Visibility: In or near an area of restricted visibility, weather by day or night

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 35(k), a pilot vessel when engaged on pilotage duty may in addition to the signals prescribed in Rule 35(b) sound an identity signal consisting of four short blasts.
Sounds two prolonged blasts with 2 second interval at intervals not exceeding 2 minutes, may additionally sound four short blasts.
Sounds only four short blasts to identify as pilot vessel.

scenario: Type of vessel: Pilot vessel engaged on pilotage duty at anchor Visibility: In or near an area of restricted visibility, weather by day or night

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 35(k), a pilot vessel when engaged on pilotage duty may in addition to the signals prescribed in Rule 35(g) sound an identity signal consisting of four short blasts.
Rings bell rapidly for 5 seconds at intervals not exceeding 1 minute, may additionally sound four short blasts.
Sounds four short blasts instead of ringing the bell.

scenario: Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 21(a), "masthead light" means a white light placed over the fore and aft centre line of the vessel showing an unbroken light over an arc of the horizon of 225° and so fixed as to show the light from right ahead to 22.5° abaft the beam on either side of the vessel.
Masthead light is white, shows 225° arc from dead ahead to 22.5° abaft the beam on each side.
Masthead light shows 360° all-round white light.

scenario: Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 21(b), "sidelights" means a green light on the starboard side and a red light on the port side each showing an unbroken light over an arc of the horizon of 112.5° and so fixed as to show the light from right ahead to 22.5° abaft the beam on its respective side.
Sidelights are green on starboard, red on port, each showing 112.5° from dead ahead to 22.5° abaft the beam.
Sidelights show 225° arc on each side of the vessel.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessels of less than 20 m in length Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 21(b), "sidelights" means a green light on the starboard side and a red light on the port side each showing an unbroken light over an arc of the horizon of 112.5° and so fixed as to show the light from right ahead to 22.5° abaft the beam on its respective side. According to Rule 21(b), in a vessel of less than 20 m in length the sidelights may be combined in one lantern carried on the fore-and-aft centreline of the vessel.
Vessels under 20m may combine red and green sidelights in one lantern on the centerline.
All vessels must show separate port and starboard sidelights regardless of size.

scenario: Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 21(c), "sternlight" means a white light placed as nearly as practicable at the stern showing an unbroken light over an arc of the horizon of 135° and so fixed as to show the light 67.5° from right aft on each side of the vessel.
Sternlight is white, shows 135° arc, 67.5° from dead astern on each side.
Sternlight shows 112.5° arc like sidelights.

scenario: Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 21(d), "towing light" means a yellow light having the same characteristics as the "sternlight" defined in Rule 21(c).
Towing light is yellow with same characteristics as sternlight (135° arc, 67.5° from aft each side).
Towing light is white and shows 225° arc like a masthead light.

scenario: Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 21(e), "all-round light" means a light showing an unbroken light over an arc of the horizon of 360°.
All-round light shows 360° in all directions.
All-round light shows 225° like a masthead light.

scenario: Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 21(f), "flashing light" means a light flashing at regular intervals at a frequency of 120 flashes or more per minute.
Flashing light flashes at 120 or more flashes per minute.
Flashing light flashes at 60 flashes per minute.

scenario: Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility Type of vessel: Vessels of 50 m or more in length

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 22(a), the lights in vessels of 50 m or more in length shall be visible at the following minimum ranges: a masthead light, 6 miles; a sidelight, 3 miles; a sternlight, 3 miles; a towing light, 3 miles; a white, red, green or yellow all-round light, 3 miles. According to Rule 22, the lights prescribed in these Regulations shall have an intensity as specified in section 8 of annex I to these Regulations.
For vessels 50m or more: masthead 6 miles, sidelight 3 miles, sternlight 3 miles, towing light 3 miles, all-round lights 3 miles.
All lights must be visible at 5 miles for vessels over 50 meters.

scenario: Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility Type of vessel: Vessels of 20 m or more in length but less than 50 m in length

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 22(b), the lights in vessels of 20 m or more in length but less than 50 m in length shall be visible at the following minimum ranges: a masthead light, 5 miles; a sidelight, 2 miles; a sternlight, 2 miles; a towing light, 2 miles; a white, red, green or yellow all-round light, 2 miles. According to Rule 22, the lights prescribed in these Regulations shall have an intensity as specified in section 8 of annex I to these Regulations.
For vessels 20-50m: masthead 5 miles, sidelight 2 miles, sternlight 2 miles, towing light 2 miles, all-round lights 2 miles.
All lights must be visible at 3 miles for vessels in this size range.

scenario: Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility Type of vessel: Vessels of 12 m or more in length but less than 20 m in length

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 22(b), the lights in vessels of 12 m or more in length but less than 20 m in length shall be visible at the following minimum ranges: a masthead light, 3 miles; a sidelight, 2 miles; a sternlight, 2 miles; a towing light, 2 miles; a white, red, green or yellow all-round light, 2 miles. According to Rule 22, the lights prescribed in these Regulations shall have an intensity as specified in section 8 of annex I to these Regulations.
For vessels 12-20m: masthead 3 miles, sidelight 2 miles, sternlight 2 miles, towing light 2 miles, all-round lights 2 miles.
Masthead light 5 miles, all other lights 3 miles for this size range.

scenario: Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility Type of vessel: Inconspicuous, partly submerged vessels or objects being towed

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 22(d), the lights in inconspicuous, partly submerged vessels or objects being towed shall be visible at the following minimum ranges: a white all-round light, 3 miles. According to Rule 22, the lights prescribed in these Regulations shall have an intensity as specified in section 8 of annex I to these Regulations.
Partly submerged vessels or objects: white all-round light visible at 3 miles.
All lights on partly submerged objects must be visible at 5 miles.

scenario: Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility Type of vessel: Vessels of less than 12 m in length

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 22(c), the lights in vessels of less than 12 m in length shall be visible at the following minimum ranges: a masthead light, 2 miles; a sidelight, 1 miles; a sternlight, 2 miles; a towing light, 2 miles; a white, red, green or yellow all-round light, 2 miles. According to Rule 22, the lights prescribed in these Regulations shall have an intensity as specified in section 8 of annex I to these Regulations.
For vessels under 12m: masthead 2 miles, sidelight 1 mile, sternlight 2 miles, towing light 2 miles, all-round lights 2 miles.
All lights must be visible at 1 mile for vessels under 12 meters.

scenario: Type of vessel: Pilot vessel when not engaged on pilotage duty

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 29(b), a pilot vessel when not engaged on pilotage duty shall exhibit the lights or shapes prescribed for a similar vessel of her length.
When not on pilotage duty, shows lights/shapes for a vessel of her size, not pilot vessel signals.
Must continue to show white over red pilot lights at all times.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel of less than 12 m in length aground Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 30(f), a vessel of less than 12 m in length, when aground, shall not be required to exhibit the lights prescribed in Rule 30(d)(i).
Vessels under 12m aground are not required to show two red lights in vertical line.
Must show all aground lights including two red lights regardless of size.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel of 12 m or more but less than 20 m in length aground Visibility: In or near an area of restricted visibility, weather by day or night

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 35(i), a vessel of 12 m or more but less than 20 m in length shall not be obliged to give the bell signals prescribed in Rule 35(h). However, if she does not, she shall make some other efficient sound signal at intervals of not more than 2 minutes.
Not required to give aground bell signals but must make some other efficient sound signal at intervals not exceeding 2 minutes.
Must sound three bell strokes, rapid ringing, three strokes like larger vessels.

scenario: Type of vessel: Seaplane

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 31, where it is impracticable for a seaplane to exhibit lights and shapes of the characteristics or in the positions prescribed in the Rules of this Part she shall exhibit lights and shapes as closely similar in characteristics and position as is possible.
Seaplanes show lights and shapes as similar as possible to prescribed lights when exact compliance is impracticable.
Seaplanes are completely exempt from all light and shape requirements.

scenario: Type of vessel: Air-cushion vessel underway Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 23(b), an air-cushion vessel when operating in the non-displacement mode shall, in addition to the lights prescribed in Rule 23(a), exhibit an all-round flashing yellow light.
Air-cushion vessel in non-displacement mode shows normal power-driven vessel lights plus all-round flashing yellow light.
Shows only the flashing yellow light without other navigation lights.

scenario: Type of vessel: Power-driven vessel towing, length of the tow does not exceed 200 m Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 24(a), a power-driven vessel when towing shall exhibit: (i) instead of the light prescribed in Rule 23(a)(i) or (a)(ii), two masthead lights in a vertical line; (ii) sidelights; (iii) a sternlight; (iv) a towing light in a vertical line above the sternlight. According to Rule 24(e), a vessel or object being towed, other than those mentioned in Rule 24(g), shall exhibit: (i) sidelights; (ii) a sternlight.
Towing vessel shows two masthead lights in vertical line, sidelights, sternlight and towing light. Vessel being towed shows sidelights and sternlight.
Shows three masthead lights since it is towing.

scenario: Type of vessel: WIG craft

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 31, where it is impracticable for a WIG craft to exhibit lights and shapes of the characteristics or in the positions prescribed in the Rules of this Part she shall exhibit lights and shapes as closely similar in characteristics and position as is possible.
WIG craft shows lights and shapes as similar as possible to prescribed lights when exact compliance is impracticable.
WIG craft must always show high intensity flashing red light regardless of circumstances.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel engaged on pilotage duty underway Time of the day: Daytime

answers.answer: There are no shapes prescribed for vessel engaged on pilotage duty.
No specific shapes required, though pilot vessels commonly display flag H or letter P.
Must display a cylinder shape to indicate pilot vessel status.

scenario: Vessel A: power-driven vessel Vessel B: power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A is meeting vessel B on nearly reciprocal courses so as to involve risk of collision Vessel A has vessel B nearly ahead on PORT bow

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 14(b), a head-on situation shall be deemed to exist when vessel A sees vessel B nearly ahead and by night could see the masthead lights nearly in a line and/or both sidelights and by day observes the corresponding aspect of the other vessel. According to Rule 14(c), when vessel A is in any doubt as to whether such a situation exists she shall assume that it does exist and act accordingly.
This appears to be a head-on situation. If in doubt, vessel A should assume it is head-on and both vessels should alter to starboard.
Since vessel B is on the port bow, this is a crossing situation and vessel A is the stand-on vessel.

scenario: Vessel A: Vessel about to be overtaken Vessel B: Vessel intending to overtake another vessel Area: Narrow channel of fairway Vessels are in sight of one another

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 34(c)(i), when in sight of one another in a narrow channel or fairway a vessel intending to overtake another vessel on her starboard side shall in compliance with Rule 9(e)(i) indicate her intention by two prolonged blasts followed by one short blast on her whistle. According to Rule 34(c)(ii), the vessel about to be overtaken when acting in accordance with Rule 9(e)(i) shall indicate her agreement by one prolonged, one short, one prolonged and one short blast on her whistle, in that order. Per Rule 34(f), if whistles are fitted on a vessel at a distance apart of more than 100 m, one whistle only shall be used for giving manoeuvring and warning signals.
Vessel B sounds two prolonged and one short blast to indicate intention to overtake on starboard side. Vessel A responds with one prolonged, one short, one prolonged, one short if in agreement.
Vessel B sounds one short blast and proceeds to overtake on the starboard side without waiting for agreement.

scenario: Vessel A: Vessel about to be overtaken Vessel B: Vessel intending to overtake another vessel Area: Narrow channel of fairway Vessels are in sight of one another

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 34(c)(i), when in sight of one another in a narrow channel or fairway a vessel intending to overtake another vessel on her port side shall in compliance with Rule 9(e)(i) indicate her intention by two prolonged blasts followed by two short blasts on her whistle. According to Rule 34(c)(ii), the vessel about to be overtaken when acting in accordance with Rule 9(e)(i) shall indicate her agreement by one prolonged, one short, one prolonged and one short blast on her whistle, in that order. Per Rule 34(f), if whistles are fitted on a vessel at a distance apart of more than 100 m, one whistle only shall be used for giving manoeuvring and warning signals.
Vessel B sounds two prolonged and two short blasts to indicate intention to overtake on port side. Vessel A responds with agreement signal if she agrees.
Vessel B sounds two short blasts and alters course to port to overtake.

scenario: Type of vessel: Air-cushion vessel underway Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 23(b), an air-cushion vessel when operating in the non-displacement mode shall, in addition to the lights prescribed in Rule 23(a), exhibit an all-round flashing yellow light.
Shows standard power-driven vessel lights plus an all-round flashing yellow light when in non-displacement mode.
Shows a high intensity all-round flashing red light like a WIG craft.

scenario: Type of vessel: Power-driven vessel towing, length of the tow does not exceed 200 m Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 24(a), a power-driven vessel when towing shall exhibit: (i) instead of the light prescribed in Rule 23(a)(i) or (a)(ii), two masthead lights in a vertical line; (ii) sidelights; (iii) a sternlight; (iv) a towing light in a vertical line above the sternlight. According to Rule 24(e), a vessel or object being towed, other than those mentioned in Rule 24(g), shall exhibit: (i) sidelights; (ii) a sternlight.
When tow is under 200m, towing vessel shows two masthead lights in vertical line, sidelights, sternlight and towing light. Towed vessel shows sidelights and sternlight.
Towing vessel shows three masthead lights for all towing operations regardless of tow length.

scenario: Vessel A: power-driven vessel Vessel B: power-driven vessel Area: Narrow channel Vessel A and vessel B are meeting in narrow channel

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 9(a), a vessel proceeding along the course of a narrow channel or fairway shall keep as near to the outer limit or the channel or fairway which lies on her starboard side as is safe and practicable. Both vessel A and vessel B shall keep to their starboard side of the channel.
Both vessels should keep to the starboard side of the narrow channel when meeting.
Vessels should keep to the center of the channel to maximize safe passing distance.

scenario: Vessel A: power-driven vessel Vessel B: power-driven vessel Area: Traffic separation scheme

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 10(b)(i), a vessel using a traffic separation scheme shall proceed in the appropriate traffic lane in the general direction of traffic flow for that lane. According to Rule 10(b)(ii), a vessel using a traffic separation scheme shall so far as practicable keep clear of a traffic separation line or separation zone.
Vessels must proceed in the appropriate lane for their direction and keep clear of separation lines and zones.
Vessels may use any lane that provides the most direct route to their destination.

scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Vessel B: Power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A and vessel B are crossing Vessel A has vessel B on her own starboard side (relative bearing STBD 054°) No change in bearing taken at interval of time, CPA=0

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 7, risk of collision shall be deemed to exist if the compass bearing of an approaching vessel does not appreciably change. Since the bearing remains constant when taken at intervals, risk of collision shall be deemed to exist.
No change in bearing indicates risk of collision exists.
CPA of zero means vessels will pass safely with no risk of collision.

scenario: Vessel A: power-driven vessel Vessel B: power-driven vessel Area: Traffic separation scheme Vessel A is joining a traffic lane at a termination of the lane Vessel B is joining a traffic lane from side

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 10(b)(iii), a vessel using a traffic separation scheme shall normally join a traffic lane at the termination of the lane. According to Rule 10(b)(iii), a vessel using a traffic separation scheme when joining from either side shall do so at as small an angle to the general direction of traffic flow as practicable. Vessel A is joining correctly at termination, vessel B should join at small angle to traffic flow.
Vessel A joins at termination, vessel B should join at shallow angle to traffic direction.
Both vessels should join at right angles to ensure they cross the traffic lane quickly.

scenario: Vessel A: power-driven vessel Vessel B: power-driven vessel Area: Traffic separation scheme Vessel A is leaving a traffic lane at a termination of the lane Vessel B is leaving traffic lane from side

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 10(b)(iii), a vessel using a traffic separation scheme shall normally leave a traffic lane at the termination of the lane. According to Rule 10(b)(iii), a vessel using a traffic separation scheme when leaving from either side shall do so at as small an angle to the general direction of traffic flow as practicable. Vessel A is leaving correctly at termination, vessel B should leave at small angle.
Vessel A leaves at termination, vessel B should leave at shallow angle to traffic direction.
Both vessels must leave at right angles to minimize time in the separation zone.

scenario: Vessel A: power-driven vessel crossing traffic lanes Area: Traffic separation scheme

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 10(c), a vessel shall so far as practicable avoid crossing traffic lanes, but if obliged to do so shall cross on a heading as nearly as practicable at right angles to the general direction of traffic flow.
Should avoid crossing lanes but if necessary must cross at right angles to traffic flow.
May cross at any convenient angle that provides the shortest crossing distance.

scenario: Vessel A: power-driven vessel Area: Traffic separation scheme

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 10(d)(i), a vessel shall not use an inshore traffic zone when she can safely use the appropriate traffic lane within the adjacent traffic separation scheme.
Should not use inshore zone if the traffic lane can be safely used.
May use inshore zone whenever it provides a shorter or more convenient route.

scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel of less than 20 m in length Vessel B: Sailing vessel Vessel C: Vessel engaged in fishing Area: Traffic separation scheme

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 10(d)(i), vessels of less than 20 m in length, sailing vessels and vessels engaged in fishing may use the inshore traffic zone. Therefore vessels A, B and C may all use the inshore traffic zone.
Vessels under 20m, sailing vessels, and fishing vessels are all permitted to use the inshore zone.
Only fishing vessels may use the inshore zone; other vessels must use traffic lanes.

scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Area: Traffic separation scheme

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 10(d)(ii), a vessel may use an inshore traffic zone when en route to or from a port, offshore installation or structure, pilot station or any other place situated within the inshore traffic zone, or to avoid immediate danger.
May use inshore zone when going to/from a destination within the zone or to avoid immediate danger.
May only use inshore zone when less than 20 meters in length.

scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Vessel B: Power-driven vessel Visibility: Restricted (vessels are not in sight of one another) Vessel A detects by radar alone the presence of vessel B Vessel A and vessel B are crossing so as to involve risk of collision Vessel A has vessel B on her own port side (relative bearing PORT 053°)
rule_refs: Rule 19 (Conduct of vessels in restricted visibility)

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 19(d), a vessel which detects by radar alone the presence of another vessel shall determine if a close-quarters situation is developing and/or risk of collision exists. If so, she shall take avoiding action in ample time, provided that when such action consists of an alteration of course, so far as possible the following shall be avoided: (i) an alteration of course to port for a vessel forward of the beam, other than for a vessel being overtaken; (ii) an alteration of course towards a vessel abeam or abaft the beam. According to Rule 7(b), proper use shall be made of radar equipment if fitted and operational, including long-range scanning to obtain early warning of risk of collision and radar plotting or equivalent systematic observation of detected objects.
Vessel A should avoid altering to port since vessel B is forward of the beam. Should take avoiding action in ample time and use radar properly.
Vessel A should alter course to port to pass astern of vessel B which is on her port side.

scenario: Type of vessel: WIG craft Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 23(c), a WIG craft only when taking off, landing and in flight near the surface shall, in addition to the lights prescribed in Rule 23(a), exhibit a high intensity all-round flashing red light.
WIG craft when taking off, landing or flying near surface shows normal power-driven lights plus high intensity all-round flashing red light.
WIG craft shows all-round flashing yellow light like air-cushion vessels.

scenario: Type of vessel: Power-driven vessel towing, length of the tow exceeds 200 m Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 24(a), a power-driven vessel when towing shall exhibit: (i) instead of the light prescribed in Rule 23(a)(i) or (a)(ii), three masthead lights in a vertical line; (ii) sidelights; (iii) a sternlight; (iv) a towing light in a vertical line above the sternlight. According to Rule 24(e), a vessel or object being towed, other than those mentioned in Rule 24(g), shall exhibit: (i) sidelights; (ii) a sternlight.
When tow exceeds 200m, towing vessel shows three masthead lights in vertical line, sidelights, sternlight and towing light. Towed vessel shows sidelights and sternlight.
Shows two masthead lights regardless of tow length.

scenario: Vessel A: power-driven vessel, proceeding in appropriate traffic lane Vessel B: power-driven vessel, proceeding in appropriate traffic lane Vessel C: power-driven vessel, crossing traffic lanes Area: Traffic separation scheme Vessel A and vessel C are crossing so as to involve risk of collision Vessel B is overtaking vessel A

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 10(e)(i), a vessel, other than a crossing vessel, or a vessel joining or leaving a lane shall not normally enter a separation zone or cross a separation line except in cases of emergency to avoid immediate danger.
Vessels should avoid entering the separation zone except in emergencies.
Vessels may cross the separation zone whenever necessary for navigation convenience.

scenario: Vessel A: Vessel engaged in fishing Area: Traffic separation scheme

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 10(e)(ii), a vessel, other than a crossing vessel, or a vessel joining or leaving a lane shall not normally enter a separation zone or cross a separation line except to engage in fishing within a separation zone.
Fishing vessels may enter the separation zone for fishing operations.
Fishing vessels must never enter the separation zone as it would obstruct traffic.

scenario: Vessel navigating in areas near the terminations of traffic separation scheme Area: Traffic separation scheme

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 10(f), a vessel navigating in areas near the terminations of traffic separation schemes shall do so with particular caution.
Vessels should navigate with extra caution near scheme terminations.
Vessels should increase speed near terminations to clear the area quickly.

scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Vessel B: Vessel engaged in fishing Area: Traffic separation scheme

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 10(i), a vessel engaged in fishing shall not impede the passage of any vessel following a traffic lane.
Fishing vessels must not impede vessels in traffic lanes.
Vessels in traffic lanes must give way to fishing vessels under Rule 18.

scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Vessel B: Power-driven vessel Vessel C: Vessel of less than 20 meters in length Vessel D: Sailing vessel Area: Traffic separation scheme

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 10(j), a vessel of less than 20 m in length shall not impede the safe passage of a power-driven vessel following a traffic lane. According to Rule 10(j), a sailing vessel shall not impede the safe passage of a power-driven vessel following a traffic lane. Therefore vessels C and D shall not impede vessels A and B.
Vessels under 20m and sailing vessels must not impede power-driven vessels in traffic lanes.
Sailing vessels always have priority over power-driven vessels in all situations.

scenario: Visibility: Restricted (vessels not in sight of one another) Conduct of vessels in restricted visibility - safe speed
rule_refs: Rule 19 (Conduct of vessels in restricted visibility)

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 19(b), every vessel shall proceed at a safe speed adapted to the prevailing circumstances and conditions of restricted visibility. A power-driven vessel shall have her engines ready for immediate manoeuvre. According to Rule 6, every vessel shall at all times proceed at a safe speed so that she can take proper and effective action to avoid collision and be stopped within a distance appropriate to the prevailing circumstances and conditions.
Vessels must proceed at safe speed in restricted visibility and power-driven vessels must have engines ready for immediate manoeuvre.
Vessels should reduce to half speed and sound fog signals continuously.

scenario: Visibility: Restricted (vessels not in sight of one another)
rule_refs: Rule 19 (Conduct of vessels in restricted visibility)

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 19(c), every vessel shall have due regard to the prevailing circumstances and conditions of restricted visibility when complying with the Rules of section I of part B.
Vessels must consider restricted visibility conditions when applying Rules 4 through 10.
All steering and sailing rules are suspended in restricted visibility.

scenario: Visibility: Restricted (vessels are not in sight of one another) Vessel detects by sound signal the presence of another vessel
rule_refs: Rule 19 (Conduct of vessels in restricted visibility)

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 19(e), except where it has been determined that a risk of collision does not exist, every vessel which hears apparently forward of her beam the fog signal of another vessel, or which cannot avoid a close-quarters situation with another vessel forward of her beam, shall reduce her speed to the minimum at which she can be kept on her course. She shall if necessary take all her way off and in any event navigate with extreme caution until danger of collision is over. According to Rule 35, in or near an area of restricted visibility, the signals prescribed in Rule 35 shall be used.
If hearing a fog signal forward of the beam, vessel must reduce to minimum steerage way or stop if necessary and navigate with extreme caution.
Sound five short blasts and maintain course until the other vessel is sighted.

scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Vessel B: Power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A is overtaking vessel B on her starboard side Vessel A is astern of vessel B (relative bearing STBD/PORT 180°).

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 13(b), vessel A shall be deemed to be overtaking vessel B because she is coming up with vessel B from a direction more than 22.5 degrees abaft her beam. According to Rule 13(a), any vessel overtaking any other shall keep out of the way of the vessel being overtaken. Per Rule 13(d), any subsequent alteration of the bearing shall not relieve vessel A of the duty of keeping clear until finally past and clear. In accordance with Rule 16, vessel A shall take early and substantial action to keep well clear.
Vessel A is overtaking and must keep clear. Even if bearing changes, vessel A remains give-way vessel until past and clear.
Once vessel A alters course, the situation becomes crossing and different rules apply.

scenario: Vessel A: sailing vessel Vessel B: power-driven vessel which can safely navigate only within a narrow channel or fairway Area: Narrow channel Vessel A and vessel B are crossing so as to involve risk of collision

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 9(b), a sailing vessel shall not impede the passage of a vessel which can safely navigate only within a narrow channel or fairway. Vessel A shall not impede the passage of vessel B.
Vessel A must not impede vessel B which is restricted to the narrow channel.
Vessel B must give way to vessel A as power gives way to sail under Rule 18.

scenario: Vessel A: vessel engaged in fishing Vessel B: power-driven vessel Area: Narrow channel Vessel A and vessel B are crossing so as to involve risk of collision

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 9(c), a vessel engaged in fishing shall not impede the passage of any other vessel navigating within a narrow channel or fairway. Vessel A shall not impede the passage of vessel B.
Fishing vessel A must not impede vessel B in the narrow channel.
Vessel B must keep clear of fishing vessel A which has limited manoeuvrability.

scenario: Vessel A: power-driven vessel Vessel B: power-driven vessel Area: Narrow channel Vessel A is intending to overtake vessel B on her starboard side

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 9(e)(i), vessel A shall indicate her intention by sounding two prolonged blasts followed by one short blast. According to Rule 9(e)(i), vessel B shall, if in agreement, sound one prolonged, one short, one prolonged and one short blast. Per Rule 9(e)(ii), this does not relieve vessel A of her obligation under Rule 13(a) to keep out of the way of vessel B.
Vessel A sounds two prolonged and one short. Vessel B responds with agreement signal if agreeing. Vessel A must still keep clear under overtaking rules.
Vessel A sounds one short blast and proceeds without waiting for agreement.

scenario: Vessel A: power-driven vessel Vessel B: power-driven vessel Area: Narrow channel Vessel A is intending to overtake vessel B on her port side

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 9(e)(i), vessel A shall indicate her intention by sounding two prolonged blasts followed by two short blasts. According to Rule 9(e)(i), vessel B shall, if in agreement, sound one prolonged, one short, one prolonged and one short blast. Per Rule 9(e)(ii), vessel A is not relieved of her obligation under Rule 13(a) to keep out of the way of vessel B.
Vessel A sounds two prolonged and two short blasts. Vessel B responds with agreement if she agrees. Vessel A must keep clear.
Vessel A sounds two short blasts and alters to port without agreement.

scenario: Vessel A: power-driven vessel Vessel B: power-driven vessel Area: Narrow channel Vessel A and vessel B are nearing a bend or an area of a narrow channel or fairway where other vessels may be obscured by intervening obstruction

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 9(f), a vessel nearing a bend or an area where other vessels may be obscured shall navigate with particular alertness and caution and shall sound the appropriate signal prescribed in Rule 34(e). According to Rule 34(e), vessels A and B shall sound one prolonged blast.
Both vessels should navigate with caution and sound one prolonged blast when nearing the bend.
Vessels should reduce speed and sound three short blasts.

scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Vessel B: Power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A and vessel B are crossing Bearing of vessel B taken from vessel A at interval of time is increasing

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 7, risk of collision shall be deemed to exist if the compass bearing of an approaching vessel does not appreciably change. Since the bearing is increasing (appreciably changing), risk of collision shall not be deemed to exist based on this criterion.
Bearing is changing, so risk of collision does not exist.
Increasing bearing always indicates collision risk requiring immediate action.

scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Vessel B: Power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A is astern of vessel B (relative bearing STBD/PORT 180°) Vessel A which is required to keep out of the way is not taking appropriate action in compliance with these Rules Vessel B which is the stand-on vessel is altering her course to starboard to avoid collision

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 13, vessel A is overtaking and shall keep out of the way of vessel B. Per Rule 13(d), any subsequent alteration of bearing shall not relieve vessel A of the duty of keeping clear until finally past and clear. According to Rule 17(a)(ii), vessel B may take action when vessel A is not taking appropriate action. Per Rule 17(b), when collision cannot be avoided by vessel A alone, vessel B shall take action to best avoid collision. Rule 17(d) does not relieve vessel A of her obligation to keep out of the way.
Vessel B may take action when vessel A fails to act. Vessel B should take action to avoid collision. Vessel A remains obligated to keep clear.
Vessel B should maintain course and sound five short blasts until vessel A takes action.

scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Vessel B: Power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A is overtaking vessel B on her port side Vessel A is astern of vessel B (relative bearing STBD/PORT 180°).

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 13(b), vessel A shall be deemed to be overtaking vessel B. According to Rule 13(a), any vessel overtaking any other shall keep out of the way of the vessel being overtaken. Per Rule 13(d), any subsequent alteration of bearing shall not relieve vessel A of the duty of keeping clear until finally past and clear. In accordance with Rule 16, vessel A shall take early and substantial action to keep well clear.
Vessel A is overtaking and must keep clear by altering to port. She remains give-way vessel until past and clear.
Vessel A should maintain course astern and only alter when vessel B signals agreement.

scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Vessel B: Power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A and vessel B are crossing Bearing of vessel B taken from vessel A at interval of time is decreasing

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 7, risk of collision shall be deemed to exist if the compass bearing of an approaching vessel does not appreciably change. Since the bearing is decreasing (appreciably changing), risk of collision shall not be deemed to exist based on this criterion.
The bearing is changing, therefore risk of collision does not exist.
A decreasing bearing means vessels are approaching and collision risk exists regardless of bearing change.

scenario: Vessel A: sailing vessel Vessel B: sailing vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A and vessel B are approaching one another, so as to involve risk of collision Vessel A has the wind on the port side Vessel B has the wind on the starboard side

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 12(a)(i), when two sailing vessels are approaching one another so as to involve risk of collision and when each has the wind on a different side, the vessel which has the wind on port side shall keep out of the way of the other. Vessel A has wind on port side, therefore vessel A shall keep out of the way of vessel B.
Vessel A must give way because it has wind on port while vessel B has wind on starboard.
Both vessels should alter course to starboard as in a head-on situation.

scenario: Vessel A: sailing vessel Vessel B: sailing vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A and vessel B are approaching one another, so as to involve risk of collision Vessel A and vessel B have the wind on the same side Vessel A is at the winward side and vessel B is at the leeward side

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 12(a)(ii), when two sailing vessels are approaching one another so as to involve risk of collision and when both have the wind on the same side, the vessel which is to windward shall keep out of the way of the vessel which is to leeward. Vessel A is to windward, therefore vessel A shall keep out of the way of vessel B. According to Rule 12(b), the windward side is the side opposite to that on which the mainsail is carried.
Vessel A is to windward and must give way to vessel B which is to leeward.
The vessel with more maneuverable sail configuration should give way.

scenario: Vessel A: sailing vessel Vessel B: sailing vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A and vessel B are approaching one another, so as to involve risk of collision Vessel A has the wind on the port side and sees vessel B to windward and cannot determine with certainty whether vessel B has the wind on the port or on the starboard side

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 12(a)(iii), when a vessel with wind on port side sees a vessel to windward and cannot determine with certainty whether the other vessel has wind on port or starboard side, she shall keep out of the way of the other. Vessel A has wind on port and cannot determine vessel B's wind side, therefore vessel A shall keep out of the way of vessel B. According to Rule 12(b), windward side is the side opposite to that on which the mainsail is carried.
If in doubt about which side the other vessel has the wind, the vessel with wind on port must give way. Vessel A must keep clear.
Vessel A should sound five short blasts and wait for vessel B to clarify her sailing status.

scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Vessel B: Power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel B has vessel A on her own starboard side (relative bearing STBD 160°) Vessel A which is required to keep out of the way is not taking appropriate action in compliance with these Rules Vessel B which is the stand-on vessel is altering her course to port to approximately parallel course with vessel A to avoid collision

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 13, vessel A is overtaking and shall keep out of the way of vessel B. Per Rule 13(d), any subsequent alteration of bearing shall not relieve vessel A of the duty of keeping clear until finally past and clear. According to Rule 17(a)(ii), vessel B may take action when vessel A is not taking appropriate action. Per Rule 17(b), when collision cannot be avoided by vessel A alone, vessel B shall take action to best avoid collision. Rule 17(d) does not relieve vessel A of her obligation.
Vessel B may take action when vessel A fails to act. Altering to parallel course may avoid collision. Vessel A remains obligated to keep clear.
Vessel B should alter to starboard, not port, to increase separation.

scenario: Vessel A: Sailing vessel Vessel B: Vessel not under command Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A and vessel B are crossing so as to involve risk of collision Vessel A has vessel B on her own port side (relative bearing PORT 070°) Vessel A is exhibiting signals in compliance with Rule 25 (Sailing vessels underway and vessels under oars) Vessel B is exhibiting signals in compliance with Rule 27 (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre)

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 18(b)(i), except where Rule 9, Rule 10 and Rule 13 otherwise require, a sailing vessel underway shall keep out of the way of a vessel not under command. Vessel A shall keep out of the way of vessel B. According to Rule 16, vessel A which is directed to keep out of the way shall take early and substantial action to keep well clear.
Sailing vessels must give way to vessels not under command. Vessel A must keep clear of vessel B.
Vessel B must give way because vessel A is on her starboard side in a crossing situation.

scenario: Vessel A: Vessel engaged in fishing Vessel B: Vessel not under command Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A and vessel B are crossing so as to involve risk of collision Vessel A has vessel B on her own port side (relative bearing PORT 070°) Vessel A is exhibiting signals in compliance with Rule 26 (Fishing vessel) Vessel B is exhibiting signals in compliance with Rule 27 (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre)

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 18(c)(i), except where Rule 9, Rule 10 and Rule 13 otherwise require, a vessel engaged in fishing when underway shall keep out of the way of a vessel not under command. Vessel A shall keep out of the way of vessel B. According to Rule 16, vessel A which is directed to keep out of the way shall take early and substantial action to keep well clear.
Fishing vessels must give way to vessels not under command. Vessel A must keep clear.
Vessel A engaged in fishing has priority and should maintain course and speed.

scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Vessel B: Vessel constrained by her draught Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A and vessel B are crossing so as to involve risk of collision Vessel B has vessel A on her own starboard side (relative bearing STBD 070°) Vessel A is exhibiting signals in compliance with Rule 23 (Power-driven vessels underway) Vessel B is exhibiting signals in compliance with Rule 28 (Vessels constrained by their draught)
