answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 18(d)(i), except where Rule 9, Rule 10 and Rule 13 otherwise require, a power-driven vessel underway shall, if circumstances admit, avoid impeding the safe passage of a vessel constrained by her draught exhibiting signals in Rule 28. Vessel A shall avoid impeding vessel B. According to Rule 18(d)(ii), vessel B shall navigate with particular caution. Per Rule 16, vessel A shall take early and substantial action to keep well clear.
Vessel A should avoid impeding vessel B which is constrained by draught. Vessel B must navigate with caution.
This is a normal crossing situation where vessel A has right of way since vessel B is on her port side.

scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Vessel B: Power-driven vessel towing another vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A and vessel B are crossing Bearing of vessel B taken from vessel A at interval of time is appreciable changing

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 7(d)(ii), risk of collision sometimes exists even when an appreciable bearing change is evident, particularly when approaching a very large vessel or a tow or when approaching a vessel at close range.
Even though bearing is changing appreciably, risk of collision may still exist when dealing with a tow or at close range.
An appreciable bearing change always means no risk of collision and no action is required.

scenario: Vessel A: vessel of less than 20 m in length Vessel B: power-driven vessel which can safely navigate only within a narrow channel or fairway Area: Narrow channel Vessel A and vessel B are crossing so as to involve risk of collision

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 9(b), a vessel of less than 20 m in length shall not impede the passage of a vessel which can safely navigate only within a narrow channel or fairway. Vessel A shall not impede the passage of vessel B.
Vessel A must not impede vessel B which is restricted to the narrow channel.
Vessel B must give way under crossing rules since vessel A is less than 20 meters and has priority.

scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel, 100 m in length Vessel B: Power-driven vessel which can safely navigate only within a narrow channel or a fairway Area: Narrow channel Vessel A is crossing a narrow channel or a fairway Vessel A and vessel B are crossing so as to involve risk of collision

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 9(d), a vessel shall not cross a narrow channel or fairway if such crossing impedes the passage of a vessel which can safely navigate only within such channel or fairway. Vessel A shall not impede vessel B. According to Rule 9(d), vessel B may use the sound signal prescribed in Rule 34(d) if in doubt as to vessel A's intention. Per Rule 34(d), vessel B may sound at least five short and rapid blasts if she fails to understand vessel A's intentions or is in doubt whether sufficient action is being taken. This signal may be supplemented by light signal.
Vessel A must not cross if it would impede vessel B. Vessel B may sound five short blasts if in doubt about vessel A's intentions.
Vessel A has right of way as the larger vessel and vessel B must slow or stop to allow the crossing.

scenario: Vessel A: power-driven vessel Vessel B: power-driven vessel Area: Narrow channel Vessel A is intending to overtake vessel B on her starboard side Vessel B does not agree with intention of vessel A

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 9(e)(i), vessel A shall indicate her intention by sounding the signal prescribed in Rule 34(c)(i). Per Rule 34(c)(i), vessel A shall sound two prolonged blasts followed by one short blast. According to Rule 9(e)(i), vessel B, if in doubt, may sound signals prescribed in Rule 34(d). Per Rule 34(d), vessel B may sound at least five short and rapid blasts if she fails to understand vessel A's intentions or is in doubt whether sufficient action is being taken. This signal may be supplemented by light signal.
Vessel A sounds overtaking signal. If vessel B does not agree or is in doubt, she may sound five short blasts.
Vessel A should proceed with overtaking slowly and carefully even without vessel B's agreement.

scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Vessel B: Power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A is meeting vessel B on reciprocal courses so as to involve risk of collision Vessel A has vessel B right ahead (relative bearing 000°) Vessel A which is required to alter her course to starboard is not taking appropriate action

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 14(b), head-on situation exists when vessel A sees vessel B ahead and by night could see masthead lights in a line and/or both sidelights. According to Rule 14(a), when two power-driven vessels are meeting on reciprocal courses so as to involve risk of collision each shall alter course to starboard so that each shall pass on the port side of the other. Per Rule 16, vessels A and B shall take early and substantial action to keep well clear.
Both vessels should alter to starboard in head-on situation. If vessel A fails to act, vessel B may need to take additional action.
Vessel B should maintain course and speed as stand-on vessel since vessel A is not taking action.

scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Vessel B: Power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel B has vessel A on her own starboard side (relative bearing STBD 130°) Vessel A is altering course to port to overtake vessel B on her port side

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 13(b), vessel A shall be deemed to be overtaking vessel B. According to Rule 13(a), any vessel overtaking any other shall keep out of the way of the vessel being overtaken. Per Rule 13(d), any subsequent alteration of bearing shall not relieve vessel A of the duty of keeping clear until finally past and clear. In accordance with Rule 16, vessel A shall take early and substantial action to keep well clear.
Vessel A is overtaking and must keep clear by altering to port. She remains give-way vessel until past and clear.
Once vessel A alters to port, this becomes crossing situation and vessel B must give way since vessel A will be on her starboard side.

scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Vessel B: Power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel B has vessel A on her own starboard side (relative bearing STBD 130°) Vessel A is altering course to starboard to overtake vessel B on her starboard side

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 13(b), vessel A shall be deemed to be overtaking vessel B. According to Rule 13(a), any vessel overtaking any other shall keep out of the way of the vessel being overtaken. Per Rule 13(d), any subsequent alteration of bearing shall not relieve vessel A of the duty of keeping clear until finally past and clear. In accordance with Rule 16, vessel A shall take early and substantial action to keep well clear.
Vessel A is overtaking and altering to starboard to pass on vessel B's starboard side. Vessel A must keep clear.
Altering to starboard violates the rule that vessels should pass port to port when overtaking.

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 13(b), vessel A shall be deemed to be overtaking vessel B. Per Rule 13(d), any subsequent alteration of bearing shall not relieve vessel A of the duty of keeping clear until finally past and clear. In accordance with Rule 16, vessel A shall take early and substantial action to keep well clear.
Vessel A is overtaking and reducing speed is one way to keep clear of vessel B.
Vessel A should maintain speed and sound signals rather than reducing speed in overtaking situation.

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 13(b), vessel A shall be deemed to be overtaking vessel B. In accordance with Rule 16, vessel A shall take early and substantial action to keep well clear.

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 13(b), vessel A shall be deemed to be overtaking vessel B. According to Rule 13(a), any vessel overtaking any other shall keep out of the way of the vessel being overtaken. Per Rule 13(d), any subsequent alteration of bearing shall not relieve vessel A of the duty of keeping clear until finally past and clear. In accordance with Rule 16, vessel A shall take early and substantial action to keep well clear.
Vessel A is overtaking from port quarter and altering to starboard to pass on starboard side. Vessel A must keep clear.

scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Vessel B: Power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel B has vessel A on her own port side (relative bearing PORT 130°) Vessel A is altering course to port to overtake vessel B on her port side

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 13(b), vessel A shall be deemed to be overtaking vessel B. According to Rule 13(a), any vessel overtaking any other shall keep out of the way of the vessel being overtaken. Per Rule 13(d), any subsequent alteration of bearing shall not relieve vessel A of the duty of keeping clear until finally past and clear. In accordance with Rule 16, vessel A shall take early and substantial action to keep well clear.
Vessel A is overtaking and altering to port to pass on port side while keeping clear of vessel B.
Vessel A should not alter to port as this will bring her closer to vessel B and increase collision risk.

scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Vessel B: Power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel B has vessel A on her own port side (relative bearing PORT 130°) Vessel A is reducing speed to avoid collision with vessel B

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 13(b), vessel A shall be deemed to be overtaking vessel B. According to Rule 13(a), any vessel overtaking any other shall keep out of the way of the vessel being overtaken. Per Rule 13(d), any subsequent alteration of bearing shall not relieve vessel A of the duty of keeping clear until finally past and clear. In accordance with Rule 16, vessel A shall take early and substantial action to keep well clear.
Vessel A is overtaking and reducing speed is appropriate action to keep clear.
Vessel B should increase speed to allow vessel A to complete the overtaking maneuver more quickly.

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 13(b), vessel A shall be deemed to be overtaking vessel B. According to Rule 13(a), any vessel overtaking any other shall keep out of the way of the vessel being overtaken. Per Rule 13(d), any subsequent alteration of bearing shall not relieve vessel A of the duty of keeping clear until finally past and clear. In accordance with Rule 16, vessel A shall take early and substantial action to keep well clear.
Vessel A is overtaking and must keep clear while increasing speed to complete the overtake.
Increasing speed while overtaking is dangerous and vessel A should maintain constant speed throughout.

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 13, vessel A is overtaking and shall keep out of the way of vessel B. Per Rule 13(d), any subsequent alteration of bearing shall not relieve vessel A of the duty of keeping clear until finally past and clear. According to Rule 17(a)(ii), vessel B may take action when vessel A is not taking appropriate action. Per Rule 17(b), when collision cannot be avoided by vessel A alone, vessel B shall take action to best avoid collision. Rule 17(d) does not relieve vessel A of her obligation.
Vessel B may take action including 360° turn when vessel A fails to keep clear. This does not relieve vessel A of her obligation.
Vessel B should maintain course and speed and sound five short blasts rather than making a turn.

scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Vessel B: Power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel B has vessel A on her own starboard side (relative bearing STBD 160°) Vessel A which is required to keep out of the way is not taking appropriate action in compliance with these Rules Vessel B which is the stand-on vessel is reducing speed to avoid collision

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 13, vessel A is overtaking and shall keep out of the way of vessel B. Per Rule 13(d), any subsequent alteration of bearing shall not relieve vessel A of the duty of keeping clear until finally past and clear. According to Rule 17(a)(ii), vessel B may take action when vessel A is not taking appropriate action. Per Rule 17(b), when collision cannot be avoided by vessel A alone, vessel B shall take action to best avoid collision. Rule 17(d) does not relieve vessel A of her obligation.
Vessel B may reduce speed when vessel A fails to take action. Vessel A remains obligated to keep clear.

scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Vessel B: Power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel B has vessel A on her own port side (relative bearing PORT 160°) Vessel A which is required to keep out of the way is not taking appropriate action in compliance with these Rules Vessel B which is the stand-on vessel is altering her course to starboard to approximately parallel course with vessel A to avoid collision

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 13, vessel A is overtaking and shall keep out of the way of vessel B. Per Rule 13(d), any subsequent alteration of bearing shall not relieve vessel A of the duty of keeping clear until finally past and clear. According to Rule 17(a)(ii), vessel B may take action when vessel A is not taking appropriate action. Per Rule 17(b), when collision cannot be avoided by vessel A alone, vessel B shall take action to best avoid collision. Rule 17(d) does not relieve vessel A of her obligation.
Vessel B may alter to parallel course when vessel A fails to act. Vessel A remains the give-way vessel.
Vessel B should alter to port, not starboard, to move away from vessel A approaching from port side.

scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Vessel B: Power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel B has vessel A on her own port side (relative bearing PORT 160°) Vessel A which is required to keep out of the way is not taking appropriate action in compliance with these Rules Vessel B which is the stand-on vessel is making 360° turn to starboard to avoid collision

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 13, vessel A is overtaking and shall keep out of the way of vessel B. Per Rule 13(d), any subsequent alteration of bearing shall not relieve vessel A of the duty of keeping clear until finally past and clear. According to Rule 17(a)(ii), vessel B may take action when vessel A is not taking appropriate action. Per Rule 17(b), when collision cannot be avoided by vessel A alone, vessel B shall take action to best avoid collision. Rule 17(d) does not relieve vessel A of her obligation.
Vessel B may make 360° turn to starboard when vessel A is not keeping clear. Vessel A remains obligated to give way.
A 360° turn is excessive and vessel B should only make minor course adjustments.

scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Vessel B: Power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel B has vessel A on her own port side (relative bearing PORT 160°) Vessel A which is required to keep out of the way is not taking appropriate action in compliance with these Rules Vessel B which is the stand-on vessel is reducing speed to avoid collision

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 13, vessel A is overtaking and shall keep out of the way of vessel B. Per Rule 13(d), any subsequent alteration of bearing shall not relieve vessel A of the duty of keeping clear until finally past and clear. According to Rule 17(a)(ii), vessel B may take action when vessel A is not taking appropriate action. Per Rule 17(b), when collision cannot be avoided by vessel A alone, vessel B shall take action to best avoid collision. Rule 17(d) does not relieve vessel A of her obligation.
Vessel B may reduce speed when vessel A fails to keep clear. This does not relieve vessel A's obligation.
Vessel B should maintain speed and allow vessel A to complete overtaking at her own pace.

scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Vessel B: Power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A and vessel B are crossing so as to involve risk of collision Vessel B has vessel A on her own port side (relative bearing PORT 070°) Vessel A which is required to keep out of the way is not taking appropriate action in compliance with these Rules Vessel B which is the stand-on vessel is making a 360° turn to starboard to avoid collision

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 15, vessel A which has vessel B on her starboard side shall keep out of the way and avoid crossing ahead if circumstances permit. According to Rule 17(a)(ii), vessel B may take action when vessel A is not taking appropriate action. Per Rule 17(b), when collision cannot be avoided by vessel A alone, vessel B shall take action to best avoid collision. In accordance with Rule 17(c), vessel B shall not alter course to port for a vessel on her port side if circumstances admit. Rule 17(d) does not relieve vessel A of her obligation.
Vessel B may make 360° turn to starboard when vessel A fails to give way. She should not alter to port for vessel A on her port side. Vessel A remains obligated to keep clear.
Vessel B should alter to port to move away from vessel A rather than turning to starboard.

scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Vessel B: Power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A and vessel B are crossing so as to involve risk of collision Vessel B has vessel A on her own port side (relative bearing PORT 070°) Vessel A which is required to keep out of the way is not taking appropriate action in compliance with these Rules Vessel B which is the stand-on vessel is altering her course to starboard to approximately parallel course with vessel A and reducing her speed to avoid collision

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 15, vessel A which has vessel B on her starboard side shall keep out of the way and avoid crossing ahead if circumstances permit. According to Rule 17(a)(ii), vessel B may take action when vessel A is not taking appropriate action. Per Rule 17(b), when collision cannot be avoided by vessel A alone, vessel B shall take action to best avoid collision. In accordance with Rule 17(c), vessel B shall not alter course to port for a vessel on her port side if circumstances admit. Rule 17(d) does not relieve vessel A of her obligation.
Vessel B may alter to starboard and reduce speed when vessel A fails to give way. She should not alter to port. Vessel A remains give-way vessel.
Vessel B should only alter course or only reduce speed, not both simultaneously as this creates confusion.

scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Vessel B: Power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A and vessel B are crossing so as to involve risk of collision Vessel B has vessel A on her own port side (relative bearing PORT 070°) Vessel A which is required to keep out of the way is not taking appropriate action in compliance with these Rules Vessel B which is the stand-on vessel is reducing speed to avoid collision

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 15, vessel A which has vessel B on her starboard side shall keep out of the way and avoid crossing ahead if circumstances permit. According to Rule 17(a)(ii), vessel B may take action when vessel A is not taking appropriate action. Per Rule 17(b), when collision cannot be avoided by vessel A alone, vessel B shall take action to best avoid collision. In accordance with Rule 17(c), vessel B shall not alter course to port for a vessel on her port side if circumstances admit. Rule 17(d) does not relieve vessel A of her obligation.
Vessel B may reduce speed when vessel A is not giving way. She should not alter to port. Vessel A remains obligated to keep clear.
Vessel B should increase speed to pass ahead of vessel A rather than reducing speed.

scenario: Type of vessel: Power-driven vessel towing alongside Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 24(c), a power-driven vessel when towing alongside, except in the case of a composite unit, shall exhibit: (i) instead of the light prescribed in Rule 23(a)(i) or (a)(ii), two masthead lights in a vertical line; (ii) sidelights; (iii) a sternlight. According to Rule 24(f)(ii), a vessel being towed alongside shall exhibit a sternlight and at the forward end, sidelights.
Towing vessel shows two masthead lights in vertical line, sidelights and sternlight. Vessel being towed shows sidelights forward and sternlight.
Towing alongside requires three masthead lights in vertical line to distinguish it from towing astern.

scenario: Type of vessel: Power-driven vessel pushing ahead Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 24(c), a power-driven vessel when pushing ahead, except in the case of a composite unit, shall exhibit: (i) instead of the light prescribed in Rule 23(a)(i) or (a)(ii), two masthead lights in a vertical line; (ii) sidelights; (iii) a sternlight. According to Rule 24(f)(i), a vessel being pushed ahead, not being part of a composite unit, shall exhibit at the forward end, sidelights.
Pushing vessel shows two masthead lights in vertical line, sidelights and sternlight. Vessel being pushed shows sidelights at forward end.
The vessel being pushed ahead shows no lights at all; only the pushing vessel displays lights.

scenario: Type of vessel: Power-driven vessel towing partly submerged vessel of less than 25 m in breadth and its length does not exceed 100 m, length of the tow does not exceed 200 m Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 24(a), a power-driven vessel when towing shall exhibit: (i) two masthead lights in a vertical line; (ii) sidelights; (iii) a sternlight; (iv) a towing light in a vertical line above the sternlight. According to Rule 24(g)(i), an inconspicuous, partly submerged vessel being towed, shall exhibit one all-round white light at or near the forward end and one at or near the after end.
Towing vessel shows two masthead lights, sidelights, sternlight and towing light. The partly submerged vessel shows one white light forward and one aft.
A partly submerged vessel shows sidelights and sternlight like any other towed vessel.

scenario: Type of vessel: Power-driven vessel towing partly submerged dracone of less than 25 m in breadth and its length does not exceed 100 m, length of the tow does not exceed 200 m Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 24(a), a power-driven vessel when towing shall exhibit: (i) two masthead lights in a vertical line; (ii) sidelights; (iii) a sternlight; (iv) a towing light in a vertical line above the sternlight. According to Rule 24(g)(i), an inconspicuous, partly submerged dracone being towed, shall exhibit one all-round white light at or near the after end. Per Rule 24(g)(i), dracones need not exhibit an all-round white light near the forward end but may do so.
Towing vessel shows two masthead lights, sidelights, sternlight and towing light. Dracone shows one white light aft and may optionally show one forward.
Dracones must show two white lights, one forward and one aft, without exception.

scenario: Type of vessel: Power-driven vessel towing an incospicuous, partly submerged vessel with breadth of more than 25 m and length exceeding 100 m, length of the tow exceeds 200 m Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 24(a), a power-driven vessel when towing shall exhibit: (i) three masthead lights in a vertical line; (ii) sidelights; (iii) a sternlight; (iv) a towing light in a vertical line above the sternlight. According to Rule 24(g), an inconspicuous, partly submerged vessel being towed, shall exhibit: (i) one all-round white light at or near the forward end and one at or near the after end; (ii) two additional all-round white lights at or near the extremities of its breadth; (iii) additional all-round white lights so that distance between lights shall not exceed 100 m.

Towing vessel shows three masthead lights, sidelights, sternlight and towing light. Partly submerged vessel shows white lights at forward and after ends, at breadth extremities, and additional lights so spacing does not exceed 100 meters.
Large partly submerged vessels only need to show one white light at each end, regardless of breadth or length.

scenario: Type of vessel: Power-driven vessel towing an inconspicuous, partly submerged vessel, length of the tow exceeds 200 m Time of the day: Daytime

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 24(a)(v), a power-driven vessel when towing shall exhibit a diamond shape where it can best be seen. According to Rule 24(g)(iv), an inconspicuous, partly submerged vessel being towed, shall exhibit a diamond shape at or near the aftermost extremity of vessel being towed and an additional diamond shape where it can best be seen and located as far forward as is practicable.
Towing vessel shows one diamond. Partly submerged vessel shows one diamond aft and one diamond as far forward as practicable.
Only the towing vessel displays a diamond shape; the partly submerged vessel shows no shapes during daytime.

scenario: Type of vessel: Power-driven vessel towing an inconspicuous, partly submerged vessel, length of the tow does not exceed 200 m Time of the day: Daytime

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 24(g)(iv), an inconspicuous, partly submerged vessel being towed, shall exhibit a diamond shape at or near the aftermost extremity of vessel being towed.
The partly submerged vessel shows one diamond shape at the aftermost extremity.
When tow is under 200 meters, no diamond shapes are required on the partly submerged vessel.

scenario: Type of vessel: Power-driven vessel towing alongside a group of vessels Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 24(c), a power-driven vessel when towing alongside, except in the case of a composite unit, shall exhibit: (i) two masthead lights in a vertical line; (ii) sidelights; (iii) a sternlight. According to Rule 24(f)(ii), vessels being towed alongside in a group shall be lighted as one vessel and shall exhibit a sternlight and at the forward end, sidelights.
Towing vessel shows two masthead lights, sidelights and sternlight. The group being towed is lit as one vessel with sidelights forward and sternlight.
Each vessel in the group being towed must show individual sidelights and sternlights.

scenario: Type of vessel: Power-driven vessel pushing ahead a group of vessels Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 24(c), a power-driven vessel when pushing ahead, except in the case of a composite unit, shall exhibit: (i) two masthead lights in a vertical line; (ii) sidelights; (iii) a sternlight. According to Rule 24(f)(i), vessels being pushed ahead in a group shall be lighted as one vessel and shall exhibit at the forward end, sidelights.
Pushing vessel shows two masthead lights, sidelights and sternlight. The group being pushed is lit as one vessel with sidelights at the forward end.
Each vessel in the group must show its own individual sidelights and the aftermost vessel shows a sternlight.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel engaged in underwater operations, when restricted in her ability to manoeuvre, making way through the water and an obstruction exists on her port side Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
rule_refs: Rule 27 (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre)

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 27(d), a vessel engaged in underwater operations, when restricted in her ability to manoeuvre, shall exhibit the lights prescribed in Rule 27(b)(i) and (iii) and shall in addition, when an obstruction exists, exhibit: (i) two all-round red lights in a vertical line to indicate the side on which the obstruction exists; (ii) two all-round green lights in a vertical line to indicate the side on which another vessel may pass. According to Rule 27(b), shows red-white-red lights in vertical line, masthead light(s), sidelights and sternlight. Additionally shows two red lights in vertical line on port side (obstruction) and two green lights in vertical line on starboard side (clear side).
Shows the standard red-white-red lights for restricted manoeuvrability plus red lights on the obstruction side and green lights on the safe passing side.
Shows only red and green sidelights to indicate which side vessels should pass on.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel engaged in underwater operations, when restricted in her ability to manoeuvre, not making way through the water and an obstruction exists on her port side Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
rule_refs: Rule 27 (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre)

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 27(d), shall exhibit the lights prescribed in Rule 27(b)(i) and in addition, when an obstruction exists, exhibit: (i) two all-round red lights in a vertical line to indicate the side on which the obstruction exists; (ii) two all-round green lights in a vertical line to indicate the side on which another vessel may pass. Shows red-white-red lights in vertical line, plus two red lights on port side (obstruction) and two green lights on starboard side (clear).
When not making way, shows restricted manoeuvrability lights plus obstruction indication lights.
Shows anchor lights plus two red lights to warn other vessels.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel engaged in underwater operations, when restricted in her ability to manoeuvre, at anchor and an obstruction exists on her port side Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
rule_refs: Rule 27 (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre)

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 27(d), shall exhibit the lights prescribed in Rule 27(b)(i) and shall in addition, when an obstruction exists, exhibit: (iii) when at anchor, the lights prescribed in subparagraphs (i) and (ii) instead of the lights prescribed in Rule 30. Shows red-white-red lights in vertical line, plus two red lights on port side (obstruction) and two green lights on starboard side (clear) instead of normal anchor lights.
At anchor, shows restricted manoeuvrability lights and obstruction lights instead of anchor lights.
Shows standard anchor lights fore and aft plus the red-white-red vertical lights.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel engaged in underwater operations, when restricted in her ability to manoeuvre, underway and an obstruction exists on her port side Time of the day: Daytime
rule_refs: Rule 27 (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre)

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 27(d), shall exhibit shapes prescribed in Rule 27(b)(ii) and shall in addition, when an obstruction exists, exhibit: (i) two balls in a vertical line to indicate the side on which the obstruction exists; (ii) two diamonds in a vertical line to indicate the side on which another vessel may pass. Shows ball-diamond-ball in vertical line, plus two balls on port side (obstruction) and two diamonds on starboard side (clear).
Shows ball-diamond-ball shapes plus obstruction indication shapes on port and starboard sides.
Shows only three balls in vertical line to indicate underwater operations.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel engaged in underwater operations, when restricted in her ability to manoeuvre, at anchor and an obstruction exists on her port side Time of the day: Daytime
rule_refs: Rule 27 (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre)

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 27(d), shall exhibit shapes prescribed in Rule 27(b)(ii) and shall in addition, when an obstruction exists, exhibit: (iii) when at anchor, shapes prescribed in subparagraphs (i) and (ii) instead of shapes prescribed in Rule 30. Shows ball-diamond-ball in vertical line, plus two balls on port side (obstruction) and two diamonds on starboard side (clear) instead of anchor ball.
At anchor during daytime, shows ball-diamond-ball and obstruction shapes instead of the anchor ball.
Shows anchor ball in fore part plus the ball-diamond-ball shapes.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel engaged in diving operations not making way through the water Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
rule_refs: Rule 27 (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre)

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 27(e)(i), whenever the size of a vessel engaged in diving operations makes it impracticable to exhibit all the lights prescribed in Rule 27(d), three all-round lights in a vertical line where they can best be seen shall be exhibited. The highest and lowest of these lights shall be red and the middle light shall be white.
Small diving vessels show simplified lights: three all-round lights red-white-red in vertical line.
Small diving vessels show only one white all-round light.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel engaged in diving operations Time of the day: Daytime
rule_refs: Rule 27 (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre)

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 27(e)(ii), whenever the size of a vessel engaged in diving operations makes it impracticable to exhibit all shapes prescribed in Rule 27(d), a rigid replica of the International Code flag "A" not less than 1 metre in height shall be exhibited. Measures shall be taken to ensure its all-round visibility.
Small diving vessels display International Code flag A replica at least 1 meter high with all-round visibility.
Small diving vessels show ball-diamond-ball shapes in vertical line.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel engaged in mine clearance operations of more than 50 m in length underway Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
rule_refs: Rule 27 (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre)

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 27(f), a vessel engaged in mine clearance operations shall in addition to the lights prescribed for a power-driven vessel in Rule 23, exhibit three all-round green lights. One near the foremast head and one at each end of the fore yard. These indicate it is dangerous to approach within 1000 m. Shows normal power-driven vessel lights plus three green all-round lights.
Shows standard navigation lights plus three green lights to warn vessels to keep clear 1000 meters.
Shows only three green all-round lights without any other navigation lights.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel engaged in mine clearance operations of more than 50 m in length but less than 100 m in length at anchor Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
rule_refs: Rule 27 (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre)

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 27(f), shall in addition to the lights prescribed for a vessel at anchor in Rule 30, exhibit three all-round green lights. One near foremast head and one at each end of fore yard. These indicate it is dangerous to approach within 1000 m. Shows anchor lights (white fore and aft) plus three green all-round lights.
Shows anchor lights plus three green lights to indicate mine clearance operations and 1000 meter keep clear zone.
At anchor, shows only the three green lights without anchor lights.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel engaged in mine clearance operations of more than 50 m in length underway Time of the day: Daytime
rule_refs: Rule 27 (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre)

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 27(f), a vessel engaged in mine clearance operations shall exhibit three balls. One near the foremast head and one at each end of the fore yard. These shapes indicate that it is dangerous for another vessel to approach within 1000 m of the mine clearance vessel.
Shows three balls: one near foremast head and one at each end of fore yard to indicate 1000 meter keep clear zone.
Shows three balls in vertical line like a vessel restricted in manoeuvrability.

scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel engaged in mine clearance operations at anchor Time of the day: Daytime
rule_refs: Rule 27 (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre)

answers.answer: In accordance with Rule 27(f), shall in addition to the shapes prescribed for a vessel at anchor in Rule 30, exhibit three balls. One near foremast head and one at each end of fore yard. These indicate it is dangerous to approach within 1000 m. According to Rule 30(a), shows anchor ball in fore part plus three balls for mine clearance.
At anchor shows anchor ball plus three balls in special configuration to indicate mine clearance and 1000m keep clear.
Shows only the three balls for mine clearance without the anchor ball.
